author: Nomograph Mastering
content:
Anyone who has experience with something like Plug in Alliance Paul Frindle’s DSM will know that it’s excellent at high mid and high frequency manipulation but at 16 bands has almost no low end resolution

Soothe has (according to a post from the developer) 4096 bins in Normal Resolution Mode. This accounts for it’s (to me) generally very blurry sound, but that can be very useful in certain contexts and if used with care in the higher octaves can be a very worthwhile tradeoff

K, won’t be around for follow up questions today but tag me and I’ll reply tomorrow

author: philbarnes
content:
Whenever I recommend this discord to someone, it's followed up with the comment that you're interacting with people who are actually making records. Not YouTube producers. Not "download my e-book" guys. This space is a rare resource and a gift in the world we work in, and it's not always going to confirm your opinion. I don't post every day because I don't always have something to say or to add value, but I do gain a beautiful new perspective on a subject from reading through here at least a few times a week that I wouldn't have had the thought of without this space.

If you're gonna go after this job for real, you're gonna have the craziest shit thrown at you from clients, collaborators, peers and heroes that you've ever heard. 

Your feelings will not be protected when you operate in this industry at a professional level. 

So, learning to take it on the chin and ask "what is there to learn here?" in a moment you're challenged is what will make you grow and be resilient. 

I just re-printed a stem an hour ago for a background vocal I fucked up "fixing" the timing of in the chorus. The client was incredibly direct and insensitive of my feelings about it, and if I hit them back to argue what was "technically correct" based on the grid and subdivisions I was looking at, and why I was right, they wouldn't care. They wanted it different, so I saw it through their lens of how they wrote the part and corrected it to deliver for the artist. And you know what? That result was better than my feeling of what was "technically correct." They were right. A beautiful reminder to serve the song rather than to check the box. 

The older I get the more I equally trust my taste and remain open to learning something based on new information. Adopting that mindset will only serve you in the process of experimentation of self and collaboration with others.

author: Slow Hand
content:
Man. I am loving the De-emphasis section on Tupe. It lets you squeeze so much saturation out of a signal without driving things too hard. 

First, you drive your signal to the point where the loudest part starts to break up, then you use the de-emphasis to subtract that frequency from the saturation circuit and then you push the gain up even harder until you're on the edge of breakup again. Wash, rinse, repeat. 

What you end up with is a signal that's evenly saturated across the entire frequency range instead of only having the loudest parts treated, because they're all hitting the saturation at roughly the same level. This thing is amazing. It's the sound that I've been searching for for soooo long.

author: oaklandmatt
content:
imho, a lot of the vocals I'm hearing from younger record makers are sounding heavily  processed in the same way. "Lack of dynamics" doesn't really explain it because people think of dynamics as dynamic range compression. It's more that everyone is chopping, clip gaining, and RXing to an evenness that softens and linearizes performances. 

These tools work beautifully when shitty mic technique makes things boomy, or there's a few weird ss's on the pre-hyped TLM mic through the focusrite pre.

But it sounds like most people who learn the tools are overusing them like crazy. 

I'm trying these days to get off the details and try as much macro-mixing as possible. When I let performances breathe in their imperfections, I find that I'm drawn in more as a listener.

"Music is the space between the notes". 
-Claude Debussy

"Music is the space between RX moves." 
-Ruairí (probably)

author: cian riordan
content: Something to chew on: bass instruments, kick drums, et all — they’re not defined by the low end, they’re defined by the midrange and high end. They’re just supported by the low end.

author: cian riordan
content: Had a fun moment today where I'm mixing this retro-ey sounding tune for a band and I was really struggling to get the rhythm section to lock in and feel really warm and pillowy. I did a number on the drums but just couldn't get the low end to sync between the two. I ended up sending the mono bass to two mis-matched outboard compressors. They're totally un-linked and I just matched them by ear and wow... sounds so fucking good. Each one is grabbing and doing it's thing and it's *mostly* adding up to mono but gives real life when things momentarily lean left or right. Reminds me of a drum setup photo today where some of the mics were mis-matched and that's just honest-to-god so OK most of the time.

author: Slow Hand
content:
A few strategies that I have yet to hear mentioned:

1) Listen very *very* low and see if the vocals get lost.

2) Listen to your mix from down the hall or in the next room. Or listen while doing some other activity that occupies your mind. Note whether anything stands out.

3) Put your mix on a tiny-ass speaker with no bass and see how it feels.

author: Colin Althaus
content:
Now if you put this HPF on only the Side channel, at 100Hz what was originally +S becomes -S (180 degrees out of phase). So any 100Hz on the left now shifts to the right, and vice versa.

So say you have a rack tom with a fundamental at 100Hz panned hard left. Apply this filter to the S channel and its 100Hz fundamental will sound like it’s coming out of the right side. But the top end of the tom will still sound like it’s coming from the left.

Very extreme example, but seen this happen IRL more than once. Easiest to hear this on headphones if you’d like to experiment.

I’ve found the easiest way to avoid this is to use very gentle M-S slopes (gentle = less phase shift), shelves and bells, and especially avoid any steep HPF or LPF (18 dB/oct or greater).

author: NoahNeedleman
content:
So there’s an old saying: if you wanna really know something, you gotta learn it, you gotta do it, then you gotta teach it. 

My friend who mentioned wanting to learn how to mix yesterday was amazed at how fast I was able to make his track sound big and loud and open all at the same time. “My mix sounded so small and congested. Yours sounds huge.”


Basically what I did, besides level & panning, was carve out a bunch of like 400 in all harmonic elements. All the tracks sounded good, but the density was all bunched up down in that range. 

As I was explaining it to him, I had a moment of clarity about headroom. Doesn’t matter if all frequencies are present for a big and tall mix, if all the headroom is getting eaten up by everything hitting the same frequencies, the collective volume of that is gonna make everything else feel quieter. 

I usually think of headroom in regard to low end and transients, but it’s true for every part of a mix.

author: Matt Huber
content:
Ah yes. The monthly tailspin, I know it well 😂

One thing that I have found to be very helpful to reduce masking / increase clarity  is to simply start by going track to track and listening for / EQing out non musical resonances and non-musical buildups. 

I am definitely NOT suggesting the aggressive hyper notching you see in a lot of YouTube tutorials, but a general track to track cleanup of obvious issues. Don’t over think it, only attack the obvious things 

Hypothetical Examples:
- weird 1.5k resonant ring in the hats and overheads…notch that thing down a bit. You’d be surprised how much space that takes up in a dense mix. 
- high lead guitar part with extraneous rumble at 200hz…not contributing to the musicality of the part…byeeee
- piano building up at 300hz in the choruses when everything is competing for midrange - automate EQ in chorus to create space 


Etc etc etc. 

Small moves like that have made some of the biggest differences for me. Definitely not the fanciest tip, but simple EQ moves have been the biggest contributor to midrange clarity for me.

author: Adam Thein
content:
Maybe I can try and distill down some suggestions from the conversation for avoiding the pit of despair while referencing:

1) Don't get stuck going back and forth constantly between your mix and your reference - you can get trapped in a loop

2) Think critically about what elements are in the reference track versus what you are working with - is there enough overlap in production and arrangement that makes this a good reference?

3) Focus on the broad strokes - I've seen it described on the server before as "where the edges are" - how wide is the mix, where's the top end sitting, where's the low end sitting, and what are the elements dominating those frequency spectrums

4) Careful not to shy away from what the track wants to be to make it conform to the bell curve

I'm probably missing a lot of things but here's a start?

author: Nomograph Mastering
content:
@BoozleBAM This is a GREAT question, and having read the whole convo twice I don't think it was really answered. Honestly I probably won't be able to answer it either, but here are some thoughts in no particular order

First the usual caveat, I'm not a mixer and I haven't mixed a record in a decade. But I did record and mix for 20 years before that and followed the whole arc from beginner not understanding compression, to pro finding my way and getting to own or use all of the baller dream hardware. All that to say I have a lot of empathy for where you are at with it. These are not definitive statements, just aspects to think about..

1) First something of a hot take that I don't see represented online. IMO compression often makes an individual instrument sound "worse". If you play and record something like drums well or acoustic guitar well, a compressed version will often sound *less real* and less vital. So why in the world would we do it???

- The first reason is that we mostly don't care about how individual instruments sound, we care about the whole song. Often a compressed sound will play nicer in an arrangement than something dynamic, real and recorded in a "documentarian" way

- The second reason is a trade off that isn't often spoken about. Compressed instruments often translate better into the wild. Take a beautiful, dynamic, real sounding, hifi & documentarian recording of say upright bass, drums and acoustic guitar. Listen in your studio in great monitors and it's a dream. Now go to Target and play it in mono on the overhead speaker on a busy saturday.....it just won't survive ... the song gets lost. Or drive with your window open, or cook dinner with the AC on etc etc.

author: NoahNeedleman
content:
Doing tracks for live-show is a different beast than making a record. 

The impact and immersion of a record vs the live show are also different beasts. The art of the live show must include the spirit of the record, knowing that’s what the audience knows, but also must elevate it or mutate in a way to make that live show tantamount, at least for the people in the room that night. The “Yeah but have you seen them live?” question is the goal of every artist (and music director) but that’s always gonna be an exclusive subset of fans with real buy-in. 

As a producer, and an MD, (who’s also been an artist,) I firmly believe the studio and the stage are unique mediums, and that each should inform, without ever hindering, the other.

author: bobby k
content: a trick i’ve loved in ableton is putting the vocoder before the drum verb and just leaving it on white noise mode. it strips all the tonality out and just mocks up the transients n stuff as white noise, then sending that to a reverb and blending it in with the drum group. creates a nice sizzle on top of stuff but also digs deep enough to feel like a verb reacting to low end from the kick. worth a shot.

author: BatMeckley
content: Thank you for the kind words. Also, I’ll occasionally put on something I love fairly late in the mixing process just to make sure I’m not WAY off. But whenever I try to match things I feel like it makes my mix more bland. I actually WANT my mix to have the bass too loud, or too much snare or whatever. A buddy of mine just listened to a rough of a rock song im doing with one of my favorite bands and he’s like “holy shit this song should just be called ‘Toms and Heavy Guitars’” and it felt like mission accomplished. I’m so bored by status quo, I want things to pop out at me, I want elements to be FEATURED. Mixing to me is less about “does this hi hat have enough 5k” and more “what are the 3 most important things at any one time in the song and can I hear/feel them”. There’s a place for knowing how to eq or saturate properly but to me that’s like wayyy behind knowing what’s supposed to be the featured part of the track. (And that’s going to probably different than whatever track I’m referencing)

author: cian riordan
content: This is a fun trick we discovered in the early days of Saturn. Eric came from tape and he was always cranking the high end on the record side going to tape to account for noise on mix down (easier to tame low end than it is to boost when you're mixing off of tape)... but there was a cool high end sheen that you'd get. So with Saturn, you just separate a high frequency band above what is really audible and just crank the gain on the warm tape setting. Obviously you can adjust to taste, but it's a great way to add a little air & excitement to some dull recordings.

someone who is hiring you to beat their mix probably never needs their mix criticized.

if they love the vibe of the muddy rough mix, it's your job to bring as much enhancement and emotional clarity as you can to something they already love. there are times to put all of your own taste into something, but those are rare as an engineer/producer/collaborator.

Eric's response was simply "it has to sound great, they're paying us a ton of money"... so everyone in the studio divided and conquered... author: BatMeckley
content:
First of all, when you’re boosting 16k, what most of the world is hearing isn’t the 16k as much as it’s the pleasant lift of say 10k up without the pesky resonance of the bell…

Also, so much of eq is subtractive, in that if I want to hear more of let’s say 10k in the overheads, low passing out a lot of the useless hash in the other tracks will make it feel like I boosted the 10k in the overheads, if that makes any sense. (I rarely want a lot of 10k in the overheads fwiw)

author: Nomograph Mastering

Clip the drum bus rather than the master, limit the bass bus more than the stereo, widen the BVs and Synths at the bus rather than heavy MS on mix buss

author: Matt Huber
content:
I don’t know how other people do it, but for me the crux of it is that, if both are occupying the sub range, there WILL BE phase cancellation when they are playing the same note. Some notes will be louder and other softer as a result. 

How you want to solve that is up to you. 

You could: 
1. High pass one and let the other rule the low end. Experiment with linear phase vs normal. 

2. Go note by note and ensure that they are phase aligned and working together. This is tedious but the results are GREAT. This is what I do 99% of the time.

author: Ross Fortune
content:
I picked up Jon and @oaklandmatt ‘s tip and started doing throws pretty exclusively directly on tracks. 

When the lead vocal is most of the way there (maybe there’ll be subtle adjustments to the LV processing, but it’s more or less up to EU regulations), I do a *commit up to this insert* (which keeps it mono, rather than a right click commit on the track title) on the whole vocal. 

I mute the entire resulting clip, then just unmute the bits I need for a given throw. I’ll duplicate this track (without inserts), maybe end up with 4 of them with different FX chains. It’s no biggie just for a H-Delay and a vintageverb/metaflanger/ whatever.

Like they mentioned on the podcast, this method encourages more experimentation for me, and also circumvents niggly things like trying to get a word to echo on the downbeat if it was sung on an offbeat - you just move the clip forward or backward in time. And if an Ess is too apparent, you can clip gain it down in the source etc.

Plus once you have your verb throw set, when you in turn commit that throw, whatever it is about seeing the audio just suggests further details like having it cut abruptly on a beat, or reverse it, or fade it in, or EQ it etc.

author: Matt Huber
content: Saturn 2, warm tape mode, single band. Pull LF back 1.8 to flatten and then trim in back -24 and output up 24. The drive knob then becomes a really gentle saturator. It can be very subtle and very nice for coloration and density.

author: cian riordan
content: With bass, I'm usually compressing the bass and getting the DI pumping how I like, then bringing the level up in to the -4 to -6 dbFS or so. Then I'll make a mono, post fader send to a mono aux with sansamp. I'll send a healthy level then start by adding a little bit of drive, then playing with the buzz, punch, and crunch to fold in the distortion -- but thinking of it like an EQ. Using it to fill in the harmonic gaps that aren't cutting through when the drums and guitars are going. Very rarely touching the high/low eq on the right.

author: cian riordan
content: They're a useful tool, but certainly not the key to having a wide sounding mix. For that, LCR hard-panning is the real move. As for wideners, I use them all the time to get things out of the middle. In mixing, I'll often use S1 or the neutron widener to spread out synth pads, reverbs, background vocals... etc. It keeps the sound in the mix, but gets it out of the way of the important stuff like Ld Vocal, drums, bass, etc. Will it collapse in mono? Sure, but who honestly gives a fuck.

author: cian riordan
content: Usually because most of the songs that come my way to mix have too many elements shoe-horned into the production and it's my job to try and make them all fit. Aggressively filtering both highs and lows is a tool I use to do that. I only find phase an issue on elements with multiple sources -- and I'm a little more careful then. But otherwise, HPF & LPFs are wonderful tools used for decades to get rid of the junk.

content: I find soothe can be really good for catching low end resonances. I actually much prefer it for that than using it to tame upper mid/high end stuff like deessing. Sounds sort of weird to me the higher up in the frequency range you go. But awesome on evening out an unruly bass or lower resonances in a vocal

author: BatMeckley
content:
So, got my car back from the shop today and they accidentally fucked up the stereo so that the amp that runs the low end and subs (and back speaker) wasn’t working, so I had to listen to music without basically anything under let’s say 300, and it got me thinking about our conversations about mixing.

I think a lot of the new (and even some of the experienced mixers here) would find out some neat stuff about mixes they like if they brought one into their daw, selected a hyper aggressive low pass (brick wall?) and then scooted it down to say 300 hz. What’s left in the song do you hear? Then down to 200. Down to 100. Down to 26. What exactly is in the low end information of the mixes you enjoy? I’d then flip it to a high pass and go the other way. How much of the bass is above 1k? The kick? I think it would be eye opening for some. 
Shawn Everett once showed me this great mix trick where he low pass something, say a vocal, and slides it all the way down until he can’t hear anything important anymore, and then just switches it from a low pass to a hi pass. (And vice versa). Pretty useful trick to make some space in your mixes.

author: Slow Hand
content:
As Justin and Zack said, there's no wrong answer here. It's achievable both ways.

But since you're having trouble getting your verbs to pop out in the way you want, here are a few things that will get you there. Usually a combination of these things:

**1.** Turn up the verb - Simple, I know.
**2.** Make space for the verb - Mute or EQ competing elements.
**3.** Increase your pre-delay time to the range of 60ms - 150 ms. This "disconnects" your verb from the source and makes it stand out more. And this sometimes means you can turn it down and still have the clarity. 
**4.** Use an echo instead of a verb - This sometimes does the thing and takes up less space.
**5.** Use a slap echo instead of a verb - One and done. Gives you that room-y feel without taking up a lot of space.
**6.** EQ muddy/thick/harsh frequencies out of your verb, so that you can turn it up louder without overwhelming the mix.
**7.** Gently apply an effect (distortion, phaser, etc) that will make it contrast and catch the ear easier.

author: bobby k

Wild how fluffy the mix will feel when everything is vaguely ~stereo~.

author: chrissorem
content:
It seems like you might be spending to much time in the micro nuances of mixing. (Easy to do that)  try a new approach. Make quick moves and jump to something else, if the kick is too….. it will remind you everytime you listen. Try  to step back and listen to your mixes like a ME. Is there too much or not enough of a certain frequency range?  Then dive back into the micro move adjust and move on. This helps  you stay in the flow and to not get lost  in the weeds.  In my experience the music tells you most of what you need to know. Tempo has a huge effect on how the low end can work. Density often determines how midrange and upper mid/ high freq should work.  The elements in the mix should be serving particular roles and that informs where things should sit and ultimately equal how it makes you feel. I don’t think very much when I mix but I react to what’s in front of me . 
The more you do this the more this will lock in. Another thing that comes to mind, is sometimes if I’m feeling like something isn’t right I’ll do a save as or In your example I’ll mute the kick and duplicate it and start from scratch and see if I can beat it. Sometimes order of operations can lead you down certain paths and as other elements enter the original moves might not being working

author: ALXCPH
content:
this is answer might not be the most exciting.

Actual Separation does not come from EQ, Compression and Saturation. These are just tool to help manipulate a sound into how you want it to sound. 

Separation comes from Arrangement. If you have a Piano and a Guitar playing full chords in the same octave, you'll never get good sounding separation, no matter how much you try and manipulate the sound.
Sounds are made from a fundamental and certain overtones/harmonics. If they overlap, then they overlap, even if you add a random eq boost on each sound some Freqs apart, because someone on youtube did that. (not that you can't do it, and it wont work)
But Instead of removing good sounding parts of a sound forcing them to fit together(whatever that even means at this point), arrange the parts so they naturally fit together with separation. This way you'll be able to act more, creatively and instinctively on how you want the sounds to sound while mixing, instead of fitting a triangle into a circle. As the good old saying says, it starts at the source, for the best results. 

Fx, in a typical jazz band, often a Bass will play roots on 1 & 3,  a piano will of then play the root and 5th an octave above that, and a guitar could play the 3rd and 7th, and together all the instruments make big full chords while also having their own space. this way there is now plenty of room for a singer or a Sax player to do its thing and not worry to much about cutting through a dense mix.

author: NoahNeedleman
content:
Man it goes both ways- sometimes if you’ve got problem frequencies or too much bottom a compressor will react to the wrong things, and depending on what you’re using to compress there may be problem frequencies imparted. I wouldn’t be afraid to eq both before and after compression/saturation. 

There’s no limit on the amount of plugins you can put on a vocal chain, so often I approach it with a lot of things doing a little bit at a time, just adding or subtracting things I’m looking for.

But if more freedoms is stressing you out, try this approach. 
Add a comp in the second slot
See what jumps out at you, and then decide if you need to eq what’s going into the comp, or just what’s coming out of it.
Subtractive eq 
De essing 
More compression/saturation
More subtractive eq/de essing 
Additive eq 
Any final touches (limiting, saturation, de essing, etc)
Fx 

Use as many plugs as you think you need to. 

Then go back and disable everything, adding them back one at a time to make sure everything you’ve done is helpful on a fresh listen. 

If you love everything you’ve done but need a little more on the chain, commit and start as if that’s your recorded vocal and go from there.

author: BatMeckley

I’ve always said that’s what I like about pop music, because pop music by definition has an objective ruler for a subjective medium. 

If I do a Low record and pitchfork gives it a 2 and NME gives it a 5 they’re both right. Art is subjective. If I do a Brittney record on the other hand, there’s an actual chart where we get to measure it’s success by; it’s either top 20 or 10 or 5 or it’s not, and there’s no arguing it. You can argue whether it was “good” or “quality” or not, but you can’t argue whether it was a hit.

author: cian riordan
content: FWIW: I never use auto align and have only used time adjuster to move room mics a little further away for effect. If things aren’t sounding locked with a simple polarity flip, I’ll quickly try and tinker with a HPF on key drum elements (kick, snare, etc). After that, I’ll resort to mountain moving EQ or samples. If someone didn’t have the skills and/or thought to record their drum mics in phase, then it’s very likely they’re not worth going through brain surgery to salvage them. Get them doing the fundamentals and move on with the mix.

author: BatMeckley
content:
One of the things that irks me most about mixes the last 5-10 years or so is how often they sound like an instrumental with a totally sonically dissociated vocal placed on top. Really takes me out of the song emotionally and makes it feel like karaoke.

I was having a conversation with Cavallo the other day and he was telling me his mix process that he learned, and it was basically “I just go left to right. First I bring up the kick. Get that sounding good. Is it doing what I want? Then add in the snare, is it good with the kick together? Ok. Then add in the overheads… etc. Then the bass, is it gelling with the previous? Ok good. Then the guitars… all the way through the vocals.” Sometimes it helps to just approach it brick by brick, making sure the building is plum before adding another story.

author: BatMeckley
content:
As someone who made a living for a while making absurdly loud mixes, I would look at trying to take the low end out of absolutely everything that doesn’t need to be there. Hi passing or shelving almost everything except the kick, and one (or two at most) bass element. And/or sidechain that low end to the primary low end instrument.

Counter intuitively, getting rid of all the bass out of your tracks can actually make your master feel more bass heavy.

It’s wild how much low end garbage is recorded by modern gear, and it just builds up over the entire session. I’d go with the Shawn Everett trick of putting a low pass filter on a track, slide it all the way down until you don’t hear anything useful, and then flip it to a high pass filter.

author: oaklandmatt
content:
first off, if it sounds good, do it. i know that starts to sound like an annoying cliche, but it's ALWAYS good to re-remind yourself. there are no rules with this shit and the more your learn about the technical side the LESS you should rely on it. because your ears are getting better and thus you should be trusting them more.

the phase shift from a bell curve is much more subtle compared to HP and LP filtering, so it tends to add back in much better when used in parallel. also there are plenty situations where you might actually *like* the phase shift, where you're boosting something like upper mid range and you get just a teeny bit of blur in the low mids. there are good articles online that graph it, but i'd say just be mindful of phase by flipping the parallel channel and seeing what it does. and trust ya ears and just do what sounds good to you!

author: cian riordan
content: By this logic, you could argue that any tool in a mixers toolbox is a band aid to a problem created in recording. Compression a bandaid for something recorded too dynamically. HPF a bandaid for something that was incorrectly recorded with too much low end. A Pultec high boost a bandaid for something too dark. Sometimes you get a vocal that has a pokey resonance that happens at 3k and if you try cutting with EQ, it kills the aggressiveness… but if you do it dynamically, it only snags it when the frequency poked 15 dB above where it should.

author: BatMeckley
content:
Nope.  Bad arrangement.
This is why I harp on bedroom guitarists vs recording vs touring guitarist. If you’re by yourself a big meaty full frequency tone is satisfying. If you’re tracking guitars youre high passing so much more than you’d initially think to make room for bass and kick. If you’re in your bedroom, a tube screamer kinda blows. If you’re in a raging band and need a solo to tighten up and cut through the mix, a tube screamer is the way to go. That key guitar hook? More often than not is tracked through something like a pignose. Way band limited.

author: Slow Hand

author: NoahNeedleman
content:
I don’t think it’s that heavy. When you come in full Hero Status, Additional Production is a completely non-threatening ask. It honors both your work and theirs. No need to make it any kind of big deal or get preemptively defensive, (hence the thumbs down on Ryan’s comment.)

When you send your next bounce, include excitement for how the project is turning out and do the ask. 

In my mind, additional production credit can be when you’re doing more than replacing kicks & snares and editing/tuning vocals. If you’re adding parts or fundamentally shaping groove elements, etc. 

But I’ve added guitar parts and replayed bass on songs I’ve mixed and not asked for production credit when it really was about making the mix work. 

It’s a per project thing I think. I rambling, but it sounds like you’re taking pride in the work and everyone is on board. Seems like a no brainer.

author: Zach Hughes
content: I am presently really fascinated by the relationship between frequency and perceived height in a mix. I feel like it all comes down to arrangement. 'Descriptive language' = 'frequency' like @NoahNeedleman mentioned feels of limited use depending on whether you are a starter or finisher of the record perhaps. It's all relative and everything effects everything. I've started to imagine my arrangements / mixes in a sort of dynamic spherical (ish) three dimensional anti-gravity space where I can push and pull the objects of my arrangement / mix forward and back or up and down. I am still exploring this model / searching for better language. My producer brain asks is all the information already there. My mixer brain asks what unnecessary information came along with the objects of my mix. You can pull up or out and forward on an object with a shelf or bell shaped boost or you can push back and away or remove altogether the unnecessary information (HPF or low shelf) suspending what remains above. I have been exploring the latter and I think it has benefited my mixes with the perception of height and informing high frequency mix decisions.

author: thecoleyoung
content:
Lots of great thoughts and technical experience already shared from Ruairi here, but want to tell a funny story on this “logic sounds smeary” thought. 

I had a production that I made in logic in 2020, and was really happy with it. We had a decent budget for mixing, so off it goes and we get a wonderful mix back. 

I was pretty new to all this at the time, and after hearing that great mix next to my shitty rough mix, I immediately thought logic had to be part of the problem cause I had heard talks of “smeary”, so I jumped ship to pro tools and have been there for the last four years. 

Come to find out a few months ago, the mixer had mixed that song IN LOGIC, and was just working from my session hahaha. 

It’s also the most streamed (and to me favorite sounding) song on that album, and was the only one mixed in Logic. 

Not trying to muddy the waters for you here, but that experience was really helpful and freeing for me! Pro tools is obviously great, and if you have the itch it’s likely worth exploring. But I haven’t found any truth to there being inherit sonic benefits from working in Pro Tools vs. Logic.

author: Nomograph Mastering

Think of your mix like Russian nesting dolls - it’s actually 3’mixes in one. The baby version is for tiny speakers - laptop, phone, iPad etc - approximated by a 400 Hz hi pass

Next is your “normal” mix - has low end but like basic car, small stereo, decent TV etc 

And last is the full range - good headphones, club, good car

author: peterlabberton
content: 👋🏻 another fan of high passing most everything besides bass and kick—and often even those elements to zero in on the fundamental, or get a kick to punch right, or make space below a bass gtr for a synth bass, etc.. It’s a habit I’ve formed to make sure I’m giving myself the maximum possible headroom in the low end, especially since I’m primarily working with tracks recorded with microphones, and you can get some wild super sub stuff you’d likely never hear but will clutter things up. And, for low-end elements, I find it can often help focus a sound. Sometimes a kick can sound much punchier and cleaner if you get the filter in the right spot, while retaining or even accentuating the fundamental and punch. Especially if you use a resonant peak on the filter. As far as phase shift… whatever. If it sounds good, it is good! PLUS you can use the phase shift to your advantage to futz with a sound that isn’t 180 degrees out.

author: Zack Hames
content:
Snare, kick, Tom’s, OHs, always cutting around 200-400. All day. 

Boost the absolute fuck out of the fundamental of the snare (anywhere from 100-200hz, tightish Q, +8-16dB)

Find a way to make the high end cool (Saturn 2 distorting above 700hz or so works) 

It’s amazing how much low end a snare mic can have and it just sounds rippin and badass instead of flat and thin. Biggest game changer for my snare sounds

author: Ross Fortune
Josh Bowman
content: Spent an hour this morning listening to mixes and reference tracks on Audeze LCD-5's MM-500s, LCD-X, LCD2, and Focal Clear MGs. After going back and forth and comparing for a while and taking breaks, I liked the LCD-X the least, just sounded weird and unnatural to me in the mid range, LCD-5s were my second least favourite which was surprising. I found Hats and things in that range had a really weird un-natural sound to them.. not sure how else to describe it. Just not for me. The Clear MG and MM-500s both sounded great, altho when i listened to some "thicker/warmer" mixes i'd done on the Focals, it felt like I would have scooped my mix too much if i'd been on them, because they were pretty full sounding/a bit boomy in the low mids/bottom, where the mixes sounded how i intended on the MM-500s. If i was buying with the intent to use them for production, or as a secondary reference, i'd probably go with the clears because they sound fun and were really comfy, have a bit more high end and bottom end.. but the mannys seemed flatter/sounded more natural in the bottom and top and more like what i'd want to hear while mixing i think.  Found a pair of demo MM-500s for a slight discount and pulled the trigger on them just now. Can followup in a week to see if after trying to mix on them i have buyers remorse or not 😂

author: thecoleyoung
content:
Another option here is just simply the performance. Four on the floor is actually really hard to get right, especially under the microscope of a multi mic’d scenario where the low end can vastly change depending on how hard the drummer is hitting. If you hit a kick or snare a little too hard or if the drummer is flamming their kick and snare hits, it can choke the drum, kill the low end, and maybe present itself as being out of phase. But if flipping the phase is solving the issue, I guess it is phase related, which is interesting. 

FWIW, if it is performance related and I know the artist is down for me to be surgical, sometimes I’ll just fly a good hit from the previous bar to replace the one that was flam’d or choked or sounds out of phase. I know this doesn’t work for every scenario, and some drummers might hate that if they found out, but I find that usually does the trick for me and blends in really naturally to a performance.

author: bryan cook
content:
check out an ever so slightly delayed distortion so you get that diction *and* the hair, just later hair. i like memory man to sansamp. the dark memory man fuzzes up well. I like to push the “punch” lower mid eq before the sansamp gain stage and then roll off bass and treble on the sansamp as well. sometimes lpf and hpf the memory man / sansamp after the fact. making this dirty slap midrangey really helps it not compete with the real or good sounding vocal and fulfill a different role.

delayed distortion can kind of be like predelayed verbs. keeping it forward and getting the vibe stuff. best of both worlds.

author: Eric Martin
content:
I don’t think saturation alone is a substitute for compression, it’s a side effect and byproduct, but it’s not gonna get the desired effect without a lot of other work.

Remember Jon works on tracks that already have baked in compression, so he’s not adding in more he’s just saturating because of density, the smoothed level is already there, and that’s also post clip gain.

author: BatMeckley
content: Again, @Zack Hames has a lot of good insight on this. As a general rule, pan hard left and right, compress the snot out of them, take out the low end, and i most of the time prefer them brighter so I can hear them. A side effect of the Melodyne generation is you can actually lock them in too much, and what happens is they start to collapse to mono if they’re too tightly tuned and timed. As with all things, there’s a sweet spot. A fan of throwing a touch of modulation on them too, particularly a LIGHT flange. Then I’ll verb for depth depending on how out front I want the lead to be.

author: samvalentine
content:
I like microshift for that kinda schmeared widening sound. I know a lotta folks here like the H3000 for stereo modulation.
Unless your doubles are hard tuned or super vocaligned I'm surprised they'd be very mono sounding. You could try is slightly different EQ curves for each side, compressing each side independently, even a subtle flanger on each side can be cool, or maybe different styles of saturation. The options are pretty endless. I believe @oaklandmatt has mentioned in an episode that he'll pitch one double up a few cents and the other down a few cents to give a wider image.

author: ehutton21
content:
Late to the party but just wanted to add that I think time away from the mix can really help this process too. It’s not sexy but it’s ol’ reliable. 

In lieu of that though, I’ll try to bring something original to the party but it’s more arrangement based than sheer mix advice (but everything starts in the arrangement!)

Resolution of tension is what makes pop choruses satisfying, both harmonically and dynamically. In theory, this emphasizes what @Zack Hames and others said—good choruses shines because of contrast. Often times, if you have a build up to a chorus or a transition into it, I like to look at the “easy to undercook” elements like risers/rev reverbs, beat cuts, and harmonic layers/white noise to ensure there’s that layer of “ooo,” “aaa,” and “wow”. Good rev verbs/risers shouldn’t just be random white noise, I find a lot of success in tuning them and then automating the tuning so the pitch rises as well. Play with that. A great beat cut on the last count before a chorus is a killer idea. Try cutting the melodic elements and leaving the bass, maybe cutting everything—listen to some Neptunes era stuff for inspo, or just more Neptunes in general honestly for pop music references.

author: Zack Hames
content:
I know a lot of folks here have been anti-dynamic EQ in fabfilter, but I genuinely love it for VO and vocals in general. It allows me to balance the low end or low mids without it sounding scooped or too wooly. It balances from word to word, almost like "Soothe" claims, but without being as destructive. I can boost low end without it having a static low end wooliness.

I don't use it for much other than that, sometimes I'll do it for a low end boost on snare with a tight Q. but those have been game changing uses for me.

author: stefanmacc
content: This might be way overboard for your problem haha . But I had this issue on a mix that was sent to me… and what ended up working for me was to basically Re-amp the close mics one at a time into my live room through a speaker. And then lay a snare or kick drum against / on top of said speaker … and re record the decay of the new drum. It sometimes helped to roll off all the high and boost the low end of the shit re amp sound to get the drum to vibrate or move more air … and I was basically able to get real drums played exactly like the original but with the specific tone / decay I wanted. Then I would just blend these new recordings to taste …

author: oaklandmatt
content:
Also, we say "there are no rules" a lot. But actually that's not nuanced enough for my taste (and perhaps, this place).

There are many great "rules." Yes, some are dumb and some are wrong, but many of them are worth learning so you know how to break them.

Things like "cut eq before you compress, boost after" is a really great rule. When you learn to do it and to hear it, you learn why it's so important (pulling low end plosives out of a vocal so it doesn't pin the compressor, for example). From there you learn how and when to break it (I like boosting the 200hz-ish body of a live snare drum into a parallel compressor/ saturator to solidify and have control of that frequency range, automate it for fills, etc.).

IMO this is a great "rule," which is great to learn and then break all the time.

author: Tristan
content:
Bobby, I want to applaud you on your level of self awareness and how much you wrestled and acknowledged your ego on this one - that’s not easy. The only info I noticed missing from your anecdote (not implying it never existed) was if there was a conversation that took place with the artist and producer ahead of time what they felt about the mix as it stood before it came across your desk. This information informs me 99% of the time whether I will mix from their session, add my own thing, start from scratch (rare), etc. 

I’ve had the opinion for a while now that over the next few years it’ll be a repeatably employable trait if you can mix from people’s sessions (including their DAWs). 

I usually find there’s still some good contribution that can be done from us, a bit of cleaning of the low end and some vocal work. It’s kind of fun when you embrace it.

Anyway, overall kudos on this man!

author: Tristan
content:
Repetition, template, predictability = reliable outcomes. 

It’s as much about gain-staging as it is providing QC’d deliverables. Both inform how you work, and you might tweak your template to make your life easier at the end.

Be a minimalist in plugins, use less complicated routing schemes and mixing techniques - go back to basics and implement more creative approaches as needed. Most sessions of pro level mixers will be 80% the same plugin(s) because they know how they react. If something reacts weirdly, or a meter is going unusually berserk and doesn’t match what they expect to hear, it prompts them to interrogate and make changes if need be - I.e. rogue low end rumble smashing a compressor.

No one single person working at a high level I know works exactly the same, but they have some kind of process in place that works for their brain and business. Some more elegant than others.

author: peterlabberton
content: Not sure how helpful this is, but: as I’ve mixed more and more, I think consciously about this less. I tend to try and find 2-3 instruments/vocals that will occupy the main focus of a given song or section, and just put those faders up and try and get them to sound amazing. Then everything else just gets gradually turned up and processed to fit in with or accentuate those primary parts. I’ll often briefly solo them to high pass and usually subtly low pass, then sneak the fader up and not touch any solos again. Getting a track a little too quiet, and then hunting around with Spectre, an API style EQ, or Sie-Q for a pleasing frequency to accentuate works well for finding a spot in the frequency range. Also I will often aggressively scoop out low mids on sampled/software instruments as I find these almost always have way more weight there than needed in even a minimally dense mix. FX may be added at any point along the line: if I know it’ll be integral to the part I’ll pop ‘em on a bit while soloing at first, if not I’ll sneak the effect in gradually with everything else playing. I definitely need to be fairly aggressive with filtering as things get more dense, particularly in the low end.

author: Eric Martin
content:
The LUFS loudness algorithm filters the low end and the top end when calculating, it’s pretty complex math.

IMO I don’t think people are using these EQs so that a meter reads louder but rather that the music sounds better when it’s louder, the distortion artifacts of clipping start building up in that range and it’s hard to build a solid mix that slams and feels good when it’s gummed up in that range.

author: cian riordan
content: And if I do HPF and notice an audible phase shift, then I'll try and work around it with shelving or different slopes. You just don't know how it's going to sound until you try it. I'm always pleasantly surprised when -- sometimes -- putting a HPF at 20 or 30hz on a kick drum will actually make it sound punchier. Sometimes it sounds worse. Gotta hear both sides.

author: cian riordan
content: Yeah, I’ll usually save HPF for the whole bus, if even… and use shelves to reign in low end on individual mics.

author: Rollmottle
content: Soothe can be a miracle worker! I've used it to tame resonances in the low mids from bass and synths, annoying ass honk on vocals, and gnarly sibilances. I find it's best used subtly, especially in my use case for correction on a master. I pull it out most often for taming build up and gnarliness in the mid range, especially as it relates to vocals.

author: Adam Thein
content:
This might be leaving the scope of normal mixing duties but a lot of times if I think the song calls for more consistent low end I'll perform/program a simple sub synth part with a preset I've made on Diva just so I know the sub is going to be always even and then blend it in where it's needed.  I'll sometimes double the same octave or do an octave below.  It's usually way down in the mix but for me it usually gets me where I want to be much faster than trying a plugin, although the only subsynth generator I have is the Brainworx one which is kind of hit or miss for me.  If anyone has a good rec for a subsynth plug I'd love to hear!

Edit: I think this comes in especially handy if you get a track with effects like chorus/phaser/flanger on a subby synth and your subs are shifting everywhere level wise from note to note

author: cian riordan
content: Well from experience, there are certain instruments that take better to additive high-mid saturation -- bass guitars, vocals, etc. Some others -- like certain brass instruments, violins, etc -- can get really harsh if you push those too far. I would start by going heavy handed on the most innocuous of the pile-up and see where that takes you. Saturation is a great way of doing this without making things pokey... but might be good to audition with an EQ first to see what zones you should focus in on. Once you have an idea of where you're going, then you can fire up Saturn 2 or Spectre or Neutron and go to work.

author: Maxim
content:
I’d say when all efforts have been exhausted to try and get stems you’ve only got a few options depending on how “badly” the beat is mixed. But generally my approach might look something like this: First pull down the volume by a bunch. Then usually you’ll want to add in some transients back again. I like Spiff for this to taste. Then sometimes Master Rebalance by Ozone can be a life saver. Especially if say the balance of some instruments are clashing with the vocal or the 808/bass is too loud in relation to everything else. Essentially I’m “unlimiting the beat”. 

Then together with the vocal in the mix I’ll try to shape the beat around the vocal with some subtle (usually reductive) eq moves. Something like dynamically sidechaining a bell on the hihat frequencies to the vocal can help a lot. Or I might also play with Spectral Shape. Some people get good results with sidechaining the vocal as a whole with trackspacer or soothe. Then if I’m missing some super lows or excitement I might throw a Pultec/Bax-type EQ or Spectre on it. 

So ultimately I’m creating as much space as possible and give myself enough headroom to still do some typical mixbus moves.

To me this removes the need to do anything different on the mixbus. Even though it’s likely I won’t be able to push as hard.

author: peterlabberton

author: ALXCPH
content: An important thing to remember about MB compressors is that you aren’t explicitly taking things out but rather re shaping the envelope of those frequencies. Which is what makes it a bit dangerous on the two buss as you won’t just be affecting the envelope of one sound. Not to be a purist at all but try and figure out what it is that it’s actually doing and how you can achieve something similar at the source. What you are describing sounds like your bass might be too loud. Or too long an envelope. There are other ways with much more control in which you can fix that issue. IMO.

author: Jeremy Klein
content:
im a bit of an outlier in this regard, but i dont really like spectre for adding high end. Sounds too brittle to me, no matter the distortion type. 

My favorite use for it is adding warmth to sounds in the low mid and lows. I really like the tube mode for this. 

I also fine the higher up the frequency range you go, the more subtle you have to be with the db boosts. I rarely have found myself using anything higher than ~3db with it

author: Adam Thein
content:
I think you are going to get a lot of varied answers about this because it'll be very different from person to person and their mixing style!  The longer I've been at it I tend to do less processing on my submix groups personally, but always have my sessions organized with them for a few reasons:

1) it can be really mentally helpful for me to try and get a track with potentially 100s of individual tracks down to about 10-12 faders for balancing
2) it helps me keep my sessions visually consistent across all the artists I work with and across styles, so I always know where to find things in my sessions regardless of track count or instrumentation
3) it can make it much easier to organize and print stems for an artist after a mix is finished if they are requested

author: cian riordan
content: This has been one of the nice things about the Grace monitor controller... have a numerical value to chase when trying to get consistency at a monitoring level. Start of day usually hits around 65 (~80-85 dBA) then once drums and low end is feeling good, volume comes down to 50 (~70dBA).

author: Ross Fortune
content:
Also, if you’ve already mixed the track, I’d be thinking to make sped up versions of both the source material (played back through your existing chains) AND committed versions of your original BPM tracks. Not to mention your return FX - verb times and predelay might need to be tweaked, possibly delay feedbacks etc. Everything’s going to change, and keeping convincing/good feeling stereo image in things like verbs is one of the challenges.

It’s hard to predict what’s going to happen in any case, so for me it’s about doing the science with your science hat on, taking a break, then fucking around with options until the voodoo clicks. 

It’s not the same mix or even really the same production at the new tempo - groove will change, relationship between rhythmic parts (the satisfying low end you fought for in the kick is suddenly slowing everything down) and consequently vocal parts and their associated time based effects all shifts.

And with all that said: sometimes just blasting your printed mix with soundshifter sync mode beats everything I just described 🤷🏻‍♂️

author: Ross Fortune
content:
~~I can’t remember which track, but ~~I worked on Hot Chip’s Bathful of Ecstacy album (mix assistant). Alexis made some last minute lyric changes, recorded new lead vocals on his iPhone and I had to slot them into a verse. Wildest Pro-Q curves you ever seen, split across a bunch of tracks with different EQ and compressors for each word in some cases. I was pretty happy with the results in the end though, pretty imperceptible after everything went through the vocal mix chain.Took ages but it was a good ear training lesson. 

@jantrit ‘s recipe above is a good methodology

*Went back and dug it out, it was second verse of this track - 1:58 "a lot to learn, a lot to earn" was recorded on iPhone https://open.spotify.com/track/2yhKDrTVMCLBWYd0aIfOfy?si=1a2914797e6843d8

It's got a low double and the FX are such a part of the character; it's a context that allows this tomfoolery.


Incidentally, just remembering some other stuff around that record. It was produced by Philippe Zdar (that particular edit was made less than two weeks before his tragic death), and I remember the stems coming in with all of their character baked in. Wouldn't say it's the band's best album, but some of the parts were awesome.

A bass guitar came in with the hihat baked in to it, so I dutifully went back on emails asking for them separated, but that was how he'd printed it - they were sharing some piece of gear, and for whatever reason that's how they had to go down. Mark Ralph was mixing it, and at the time I might've had a bit of a "huh, Zdar's supposed to be a professional, why is the hi hat on the bass channel" sort of bullshit attitude, but that particular instance cleared that right out. Mark's response to anything like that was always pure acceptance and understanding that people work how they work and it's his job to do what he can with whatever he receives.

author: NoahNeedleman
content:
Honestly it’s not as hard or scary as it sounds, and the more pro they are the more they’re likely to understand or know already what you’ll be wanting to do. 

Something as simple as “when the bass is playing in the upper ranges it sounds dope but I lose some of the sub info that makes the chorus feel tall. Cool if I layer in a sub bass?” Or “I want the to get a little wider, you up for me tossing some guitars at it for more more info on the sides?” 

Clear communication about the “why” of it usually makes it easy. 

Cc @CK

author: LAPhill
content: Gullfoss was really handy when mixing the whistling from the session last week. I used it subtly, and reduced the frequency range that it was affecting, but it did a great job of knocking down all sorts of weird resonances and overtones. Soothe probably could've done something similar, but I don't have it. IME "Tame" at about 10% is all you need for it to clean things up without causing problems. "Recover" usually doesn't do anything good.

author: peterlabberton
content: Trying to match stuff by ear is a great learning opportunity (not trashing EQ match). Recently was trying to punch in vocals on half a bridge on a song recorded a year earlier in a different studio with a different engineer on a different mic. Just AB'ing back and forth and going, "ah, yep, it's a little brighter in the old recording..." and then poking around and trying to find out the right spot to boost... going back, "okay, now it feels a little boxy..." etc. etc.. When you get down to it, things are usually simpler than you think. It's bright, it's dark, whatever. You address it, and learn/train your ear in the process. And if you're a little lucky and kinda know what you're doing, often you can get pretty close pretty quick. 🙂

author: Ross Fortune
content:
I struggle with this sometimes. My instinct is to make everything explosive, generally in a fairly heavy handed manner. I’ve occasionally tried to temper that instinct and gone in with kid gloves, but whenever I’ve ignored the Smash Smash Demon on my left shoulder, I end up wasting the day making overly subtle moves that add up to “completely fine” mixes. 

I listen back the following morning, think “fuck this”, smash the everliving fuck out of everything as I should’ve done in the first place, and end up with a much more satisfying and engaging version.

Obviously it’s horses for courses, and how the material comes in is going to dictate what needs doing, but I’m starting to think that this instinct to energise / grab attention / inflate to larger-than-life proportions might be my USP. This is what all of my mixes that I still like seem to have in common (apart from sounding shite).

Beyond my own little therapy session here Noah, this post is intended to suggest that “gently gently” might not be the way (not having heard the track of course), and maybe the move is to juice *everything* up a couple of notches. Juiced gtr might sound “processed” in comparison to the current flat drums, but if you juice the drums up too, and then the bass, the contrast might not be so apparent. 

Let us know about the outcome.

author: peterlabberton
content: I've had some good results from time to time just being ruthless cutting the bottom octave with a low shelf. There's usually still *plenty* of sub info, and you rather cleanly accentuate some of the harmonics above the fundamental that way.

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: Yep, in production/mixing if it’s better you should do it. What I do counsel people against is the typical online advice of “high pass everything to clean up the low end”. Better advice is find a bass player who can play properly to clean up the low end! Better yet is get decent monitoring so you actually meet the record and hear the effect of these filters. author: sethearnest
content:
*A* way but not the only way: I'll try to pick only one or two things to really carry the 'weight' of the warmth and clean up other things in that range. Helps overall keep the perception of warmth without the mud. 

And never afraid to move/automate/dup-and-change-settings depending on the section of the song. As an ex.: if a verse is ac gtr and vocal only, the ac gtr can carry a lot of weight. When the band kicks in, you can thin out the ac gtr and let bass or something else carry some of it.

author: cian riordan
content:
General Feedback:
* Improve the snare to add more depth and body: Sure, because nothing says "hit record" like a snare that can double as a comfy pillow.
* Ensure better distribution of drum cymbals in the sonic landscape: Why not create a cymbal maze for listeners to navigate, with the possibility of getting lost in a crash?
* Make the piano a touch louder than the guitar: It's a battle of the keys vs. strings, but I guess the piano is tired of playing second fiddle... I mean, guitar.
* Enhance bass presence, particularly subtonic frequencies: Let's make the earth shake with those subtonic frequencies. Earthquake warnings for the neighborhood, anyone?

author: cian riordan
content:
Couple of random thoughts:
1. If the synth is extremely subby, consider pushing in some midrange via EQ or saturation to help definite it in the mix. Sometimes these synth basses are swimming in sub and the more you turn them up, the more it eats up headroom while still not really being able to hear it.
2. Are you competing against other low end sources outside of the kick? If so, you’ll have to divide and conquer the frequency ranges and let each one live in a specific zone. For example, if you have a bass guitar, make sure that its voiced in the fundamental 200-400hz area and leave the sub handle things below the kick.
3. Utilizing the analyzer in Pro-Q3 can be helpful for finding conflicting frequencies. You can throw Pro-Q3 on say the synth bass and the kick track, then on the synth bass instance, pull up the kick as a secondary histogram in Pro-Q3 and you’ll have a nice visual representation of where the kick is trying to punch through. You can then use some creative cutting to carve room for the kick. Or vice-versa.
4. Sometimes when nothing is working with synth bass and I need to do something drastic, I’ll delay one side of it 30mz to widen it out and get it out of the center. This can fall apart in certain mono-situations, but will often clear way for more bass instruments and the kick drum if done right.

As always, all of this is dependent on everything. YMMV.

author: NoahNeedleman
content:
Fun little adjustment to my mix world currently, based a little on @oaklandmatt’s reminder about boosting snare frequencies into a compressor for a certain pump. 

I tend to like to boost 1.5k on my bass tracks for grind & presence, but I moved that boost before the compressor and the way it reacted was reallllly pleasant. Evened out the overall dynamic control and moved the sound from slight tub & grind to even and gritty. 

 I know I can’t be the first guy to do this but it’s fun when it feels like your idea.

author: chrissorem
content: This is interesting, I do agree there are  often times decisions aren’t being made. I find that this is a side effect of everyone having the ability to be able to record from their home or wherever. It’s becoming more rare to have a record made with the traditional producer/engineer team working on a record From beginning to end. It’s more common a band will come in and track basics take it home for a few weeks try a bunch stuff out in their untreated room where they really can’t tell if they are adding something to the arrangement that’s muddying up a the song or if it  needs a different mic, positioning or eq ect. Or if in fact  it’s an orchestration issue.  Regardless they add it and send it to a mixer and say it sounds shitty because it hasn’t been mixed yet.  This is where I disagree with the whole “they’ve been living with it for however long so just make everything better than what they had”. Serban says somewhere down the line decisions haven’t been made. So even though I might get push back I’m going to try to do whatever  it is I think will make the mix better even if it’s crossing over into  the role of production. I can always give them back what they had but often the mix needs some things muted and calls for some big moves when the scenario above happens. I know some productions are not this case and require light lifting but in my world that hasn’t been the case.

author: James Cronier
content:
I’m wondering if anyone else has had this experience but for me, I was trying to lean on the mix bus to sort out things better resolved in the mix. 

I also found that by simplifying the mix bus, the choices I make on individual tracks come through clearer. A subtle 0.3dB move on a fader is much more audible to me when it’s not going through an 2 EQs, 2 compressors, a saturation thing, some kinda imager, and a limiter.

Instead all my hard work is done at the tracks themselves, and pulled forward slightly at the bus.

author: Moses Mastering
content:
As a mastering engineer, I’ve kept my monitoring level consistent for the past ten years—at a relatively low volume. This isn’t a rule, just my approach, and I do it because I know exactly how a finished track should sound in my room at that level.

Every system has a sweet spot, and if you can identify that in your setup, you’ll get more consistent results. This ties into factors like speaker and amp combinations, how your speakers push air—especially in the low end—and how they perform at different volumes.

Many speakers don’t reproduce low frequencies accurately when played too softly. On the flip side, when pushed too hard, speakers often cap the low end, meaning the bass stops getting louder while the mids and highs continue increasing. This is common in everyday listening setups—people crank their systems beyond their limits, causing an imbalance where the top end dominates.

This is one reason why working with a mastering engineer with a well-calibrated setup can be beneficial. But that doesn’t mean there’s only one way to do things—some engineers work in less-than-ideal setups and still get great results. It all comes down to what works for you and gets you the sound you like.

One thing that’s important to remember which i amsure you already know.... your ears perceive frequencies differently at different volumes—this is a well-documented, non-linear effect. The way we hear balance changes with loudness, which is why understanding how your room and speakers respond at your chosen listening level can make a huge difference in achieving consistent, reliable masters. If you crank it... "memorize" in your ears how it should sound cranked. Then when you drop down to another level.."memorize" how it sounds there. You should then find a few spots you can use.

author: Chad Rodgers
content:
I also love what Jack’s said here and I’ve got to keep remembering this.

I imagine the average listener is way better at hearing the _intention_ behind a record - versus hearing the quality or size - than many record makers would give them credit for.

It’s similar in a way to how songs like Seven Nation Army and Mr Brightside sound MASSIVE in our heads but are actually quite small, distorted and boxy in the mix. The intention hits us first and as a listener our imagination takes us the rest of the way.

It’s also why your heart is left flat sometimes when, as a fan, one of your favourite artist’s songs goes from demo/early EP version to super polished major label album version.

author: cian riordan
content: I like using Tupe for this. Boost that area on the EQ section then drive the “tubes” a little bit. A nice not subtle, but not overcooked way of doing it. Plus you don’t get all the compression artifacts if your vocal is already sufficiently contained dynamically.

author: cian riordan
content: The Ozone widener lets you breakup the frequency spectrum so you can leave the midrange or low end alone and just widen the high frequencies. Can be a nice zest at the end of a mix.

author: NoahNeedleman
content:
A bell dip just above the fundamental (the bottom of the notes) will often lead to a subbier sounding bass. 
So let’s say all the lowest notes live around 40hz, if you dip at 50 or 60 the bottom becomes more apparent. 

If I just wanna *hear* the bass more I’ll usually goose around 1.5k

It doesn’t always work, but it’s a useful technique Kaplan taught me

author: Rollmottle
content: Loudness doesn’t come without tradeoffs and only you can know what the right trade offs are for your music. Limiting can certainly degrade the listening experience if done poorly. Your theory that limiting inherently degrades the listening experience because there are “artifacts” is voodoo. Being laser focused on artifacts that are only audible upon going out of your way to listen for them with a high pass filter is getting a bit lost in the sauce. I’d take a step back and focus on getting the music to feel good, not whether somebody might find limiting artifacts in your music if put under an electron microscope. Alternately, you can also simply make quieter records.

author: j A m E s
content: FYI: Ya’ll using theT-Racks clipper, beware if you don’t want this, actually has a built in high pass filter!

author: ALXCPH
content: I wouldn't. Low cutting a sound that does't have any low-end can actually do more harm than good.  You can try it your self. Find a sound that sounds like you want it to, that doesn't have any low ned problems. now try a do a High-pass filter and look at the peak meter. It will most likely peak higher than it did before, with no audible benefits. Only do a High-pass filter, if you need to remove low-end, thats creating a problem or taking up space. low cutting to *be safe* is generally not great practice. Also if you do a lot of low cuts, vary the cutoff points or you will get a build up of that frequency. Lets say if you low cut everything at 100Hz... you will end up with a bump at 100Hz. So just be weary of that. 😇

author: cian riordan
content: Absolutely. Thats why I love setting a level against a reference once I get drums and bass happening and then just not thinking about it. More often than not, I'm landing at -9 or -10 LUFS with little to no limiting by the time I send to mastering, so I'll then trim down 5dB and give the ME all the headroom. I don't give the option of my full-level master... I personally think it's pretty dumb to back them against the wall like that.

author: Josh Bowman
content: A lot of times automation or splitting the higher melodic parts off to a separate track works best for me… obviously depending on how high the note is there will inherently be less bass, sometimes I’ll add r bass or lo air to the higher ones really subtley, but I rarely do this. Usually the higher notes are just higher so they naturally don’t have sub/super low end info, which I’d say is more an arrangement issue than mix issue, if the track feels empty in the low end down there during the parts the bass is up high and it was unintentional. What have you tried so far?

author: Zack Hames
content:
You’ve got the right idea - The more different the left and right, the more wide it will feel. So you can change timing, pitch, and timbre/tone when double tracking to make it wide but also balanced. For example, double tracking guitars, keep the same guitar cab and guitar but different amp head. Or different pickups from the same entire rig. Etc. 

There have been a lot of good tips for layering vocals, to have the harmonies be different mics and preamps or simply stepping away from the mic to get more distance. 

As far as plugins and stereoizing, even a simple pitch shift plugin can do a lot. Delay 15-30ms each side, pitch +/- 5-10 cents, can get a cool effect if used subtly

author: cian riordan
content: AutoAlign is a cool tool, and definitely useful in situations. But if you're mixing a song and need to scoop mud out of a particular mic thats sounding too tubby, its just far quicker to reach for an EQ and get to work. The perceived sonic impact of that is negligible in my experience.

author: peterlabberton
content:
Hey!

I have it on my mix print track (I’m old school like that), along with an instance of Pro-Q3 and iZotope Insight. These three are always open on a second screen to my side. I have Tonal Balance set to the Fine mode, with the Modern curve preset, and with 5 second averaging instead of the default 10. I mostly just check it once I have a mix pretty much put together to see if I’m missing anything as a dummy check, but I’ll also look at it when comparing to a ref or playing with kick/bass levels. Sometimes it’s also helpful to find a spot for a final element or two I’m trying to shoehorn into a dense arrangement—but for that I usually just pull up Spectre and push frequencies around until things sound good. (The instance of Pro-Q3 is for seeing more fine detail, and Insjght I’m just using to measure loudness.)

author: peterlabberton
content: I've got a (UAD) Pultec I mix thru for this, and it's on from the very start. Just really broad low and high boost. This quite often means I'm cutting some low lows out of my kicks/basses, but everything else warms up nicely with this, and—since I'm *mostly* mixing instruments recorded with microphones in a room—this gets me a good headstart to push some energy out of the midrange and make things more full and finished sounding from the get go.

author: Jeremy Klein
content:
i started doing this at the beginning of the year and was probably the biggest improvement for the consistency of my mixes:

1) use _one to two_ reference track that i think the tonal balance is perfect (for me 7 rings by ariana grande lol)
2) have it in Adapter Metric AB looped at the chorus of that song and assign the A/B switch to a key command
3) hit the key command while your track is playing and reference a short 3 second burst than go back to your track

The only thing im listening for is stuff that is _completely_ out of whack that jumps out immediately. Like "WHOA there is _way_ too much 1k in my vocal" Anything more subtle is going to throw me down a rabbit hole of trying to match 2 completely different songs.

author: NoahNeedleman
content:
Like @Eric Martin said, it’s not a hard & fast rule, but the philosophy is this:
Think about what goes in the middle, and think about what goes on the sides; pan accordingly. 

I tend to think the only things that truly occupy the middle should be kick snare bass and lead vocal. but of course every rule is meant to be broken. Hence the word “primarily” in my note to self.

author: Eric Martin
content:
I mix through my analog tracking/mastering gear sometimes, but that’s usually just printing in and getting a vibe. A significant number of my recalls for mixing end up being this up this down, but not as much, it’s foggy sounding between the bass and drums. If I got more feeling notes I might be more inclined to go back and recut/re-commit those parts but being able to commit in analog and doing the bulk of tone shaping with analog this way vs down to a console I can get by using outboard without fucking with recalls.

I almost always am closer to a good mix with my hands on the controls vs a mix I do with eyes and my mouse.

author: peterlabberton

Shit can get resonant down there just like it can in the midrange, especially with real instruments and inexperienced players.

author: spectrummasters
content: If its any help, fwiw , imo It’s absolutely all about your gain structure and groups, and it’s kind of counter intuitive , you don’t want to be slamming anything ...just very careful db clipped here, db limited there ....across your buses . I have 6 group buses: . Kicks , 808/Bass , Drums , Music, Vox , FX and only clip by 1-2 db at the mixbus . Nothing clips by design or accident anywhere else .....for rnb/hip hop build your mix the Alex tumay / mixed by Ali way , get that 808 up first, on its own ....as loud as you want it , then build everything around it afterwards. Filtering is your friend. Have nothing in the low end but your bass. Overall I’d absolutely suggest watching Jon castelli mixing t Shine (he uses clipping well in there ) and mixed by Ali mixing YG , his mix balance and grouping is CHOICE. I say  somewhere between these two is the perfect rnb/hip hop mix lol . PS. I wouldn’t  do any of that edm/clip to zero stuff, it doesn’t work for anything other than serum madness.

author: Deleted User
content:
Depending on the tools at your disposal and the exact situation I have a few suggestions:

Look for some low end in the performers vocals. Boosting with SPECTRE is nice but any eq can help add weight to a vocal if you’re boosting correctly. I would suggest having the dynamics tamed to your liking before boosting low end in a vocal because it can easily get out of hand

You could try duplicating the take, use RX de-reverb or whatever you can to remove as much ambience as possible, compress it heavily and blend it in. Obviously compression will bring out ambience so as to not let that become an issue try removing it beforehand. 

AVOX duo is a neat trick I use sometimes to help give a vocal some dimension. I use it on a send.

author: jantrit
content: Never having tried eq match I can’t talk on that but I’ve had good luck doing an ‘eq match’ myself on a number of occasions. Pick the one mic you want to replicate and slap an eq on the other. Listen between both and just use your ears to get as close as you can until it’s not an issue anymore.  More often than not you can get them close enough that no one will be able to tell. Start with broad strokes “this one has more low end” boom add some low to the other. Then slowly starting to narrow in making smaller and smaller adjustments until it feels right.

author: Rob Domos
content: This is also the biggest reason that analog synths have so much more solid of a lowend than any digital synth. It’s not the saturation giving you that solidity. It’s that hardware LPFs don’t have anywhere near the same amount of cascading delay differential. I.e. a software bass synth by default has a slight reverb that is phase canceling itself wellllllll into the passband (like all the way down iirc) just by the nature of it having a digital LPF bottlenecked at 44.1, where a moog filter has very little of that going on because the sample rate of the real world is infinite, or the speed of light, depending on how you look at it.

author: cian riordan

Basically, he puts white noise on his mix bus to get to whatever his desired overall program level (he was using VU meters)... then one by one, he starts introducing elements (drums, bass, etc) until they are just slightly louder than the white noise, then lowers them just a bit so they're inaudible. Once he did this with all the elements, then he peels off the white noise and you supposedly have a pretty balanced mix. I haven't been able to try this because *reasons* but was curious if anyone here caught it and gave it a go...

author: cian riordan

But for sun heavy pop, I send the low end out the other pipe so it’s not overly driving the compressor and/or distorting that low end. It’s been working well thus far

author: Iwan Morgan
content: Thinking about this again… if it’s usually not exciting enough for me when i’m working it’s probably because I haven’t fully prioritised anything in the mix and tried to make it too pleasant. We have to find what it is that excites us about the track and make it more exciting to communicate to us. Sometimes that’s turning down the drums to make them smaller and making the balance be led by acoustic guitars. Like Big Star or Teenage Fanclub and not a banging War on Drugs style of thing. I mixed an electronic thing recently and made it all sound too big when my initial joy was that the track was going down a Cluster, Harmonia, Neu! style. Only way I unclocked it was to make the rhythm and bass smaller and thinner and then the whole thing got more exciting.
