author: Dusk
content:
1) Goodhertz is known for its UI. I find Faraday to be intuitive in a way other limiters aren't for me. The ability to alter the saturation is great. The warmth slider that makes a sound feel warmer or cooler is super fun to me. It's not transparent, but the limiting is gentler, so I like it guiding a sound into its place. Its goal is to make the overall artifacts of limiting more pleasing
2) I find it faster, more versatile, and better for limiting than a Vari-Mu emulation. Not to mention the UI is way more helpful than what I'm used to with a plugin looking to remind us of a Fairchild or similar
3) Yes, it just doesn't brickwall, and it has a vibe
4) You don't Need Tupe if you have a saturator you already like, but I adore it. I was skeptical at first, but I demoed it on drums, and it changed my life. Always on drums and bass guitar for me. Again, Goodhertz's UI makes it more versatile than any other Tube and/or Tape emulator I've seen. It has a million options to tailor the saturation. The Opto Compressor and simple EQ are fast and versatile. It sounds good

author: Ingmar Carlson
content: On the subject of over-flattening vocals, I think we're definitely dealing with a cultural feedback loop of sorts here, not dissimilar perhaps to what's happened over the past few decades with autotune. More and more people are accustomed to vocals feeling this way, and not just dynamic flattening with overcompression, but emotional flattening as well. People are referencing vocals that feel like this. And by the time things get to us, they're often sufficiently dehumanized to the point where trying to inject more "natural" dynamics etc is already a fools errand

author: Brian Reynolds
content: I made it up. Take a synth for example. Set up a parallel send bus. Put the panner on the send. I usually compress it to smithereens. Blend it in underneath the main signal. You can get a lot of cool subtle movement. That can fill in the audio spectrum nicely. As example above could use subtle movement to fill out a pad. Or there are more adventurous circular 3D panning options that I find work well top end arps or vox chops. It was an idea born out of how people use 1/8 ping pong delays to fill out behind Bass guitar. Basically a different way to have the audio swim around subtly behind the main source. Try it. It's fun

author: Ross Fortune
content:
Further to @chrissorem ‘s note, I mixed a show a while back with 23 songs, big production for each. For me it made more sense to keep the drums on the same channels all the way through with minor tweaks once the balance was set, but duplicate the tracks for bass, synths, guitars, vox etc for each song. 

That way I could go in on treatments and processing, grab faders and mix with abandon without having to think about what preceded or followed. 

I kept the tracks for each song in folders and made them inactive when things got out of hand CPU wise. I just made 2 or 3 songs active at a time so I could print the transition from one to the next for the final mixes.

Bluegrass might be less complex 😂

author: Brendan Trinkle
content:
+1 for Adobe Enhance – post audio is my day job & it's a lifesaver. Budget some time though, you'll have to upload clip-by-clip, process, and download again, which is a pain for feature length material. 

Doing a pass in RX before processing via Enhance can help it better understand buried DX sometimes. Try using Dialogue Isolate for this to boost dialogue level. 

Keep raw tracks available under your Enhanced tracks so you can quickly sub out any AI-garbled lines.  

I would suggest enhancing only enough to bring DX forward in those clips – improvement over perfection – and consider committing to an Enhance cleanup percentage per scene (the “amount” slider in Adobe’s interface). Documentaries especially can be forgiving with less than ideal capture, and the goal should be consistency – especially with background noise. If something remains unintelligible despite your efforts, encourage them to use subtitles. 

Good luck!

author: cian riordan
content: This is why not leaning on the master bus compression too much is a good idea. Try subgrouping your instruments (drums, bass, guitars, synths, etc) and doing heavier compression on those sub-groups. That way if you turn up a synth it will only impact the compression scheme on that bus and not jam down the mix bus.

author: jonmatteson
content: As a drummer  I learned that I don’t like high passing most drum inputs besides the hat and overheads. The phase shift that happens after you’ve gotten everything in phase tracking is annoying to chase and usually a low shelf will do the trick without as many phase issues if things were tracked properly.

author: BillyC
content: An allpass filter is really better suited for that specific kind of tweak because it allows you to do exactly that without compromising on any useful low end.  Obviously a thinned out drum sound is a vibe, but when it's not I leave overheads full range 99% of the time!

author: Slow Hand
content:
I'll bite. Delay lines and feedback loops (the building blocks of a delay unit) have massive utility in audio DSP. With a simple delay unit you can:

Adjust phase relationships
Construct a filter (LPF, HPF, EQ band, etc)
Create echoes
Create chorusing
Create phasing and flanging
Create a tuned resonator
Build a non-granular pitch shifter (think a whammy pedal or a boss shifter)
Build a network of interconnected delay lines and thus a reverb unit

There are plenty more use cases that are slipping my mind right now so.... delay till I die.

author: sethearnest
content:
For sync most of the time they want actual sub-mixed stems per inst group, not multitracks, so a drum mix, bass, guitars, etc, as separate stems all adding up to the stereo mix. So whatever’s a part of the busses /subgroups adding up to the stereo mix should be left on. 

The reason why: Most of the time they’ll use the stereo mix in my experience, but if something like a shaker or lead synth is wailing away under a dialog moment, or something like a boomer is messing up a sound effect, they’ll bust into the stems to mute those conflicting elements, but they’ll want the song/mix to generally sound the same. 

So for sync stems, they may have deliverable specs already, so doesn’t hurt to ask, but if not, I always try to put myself in the mind of an editor and approach stem splits with the idea of “if it could be distracting, it gets its own stem.” Generally, aside from basic inst groups, I’ll split out high perc stuff, boomer/swooshers/lifters, any leads/solos, and of course vocals always get split lead and BGVs as separate stems.

author: Zack Hames
content:
I almost never use multiband comp tbh. I use multiband saturation all the time with Saturn.

The general reason i use it is to brighten something without simply adding a high shelf, or to create a broader wider transient on a drum track. The distortion with splay out the sharp transient. So I’ll saturate high end on vocals or bass to get more openness without harsh high end boosts, I’ll use the same sort of settings on close mics on acoustic drums to get more attack and punch. 

This is an Oversimplification but Nothing is bad in excess if it sounds good.  There are no rules.

author: Will Melones
content: To piggyback on multi-mic'd sources, I've been using AutoAlign on drums lately, and I'm not convinced that I always prefer what aligning all the mics does. Yes, there's more low end in the kick and snare, but is that always desirable? If you're going to end up EQing that buildup out of the drum buss, why not let the organic phase relationships do some of that work for you

author: Will Melones
content:
I have two thoughts on this. One is to use balance (often fader automation) to bring attention to a particular track moment by moment. Maybe multiple midrange elements will be competing, but the ear can only focus on one at a time (in addition to the drums, bass, and maybe vocal) so YOU choose and shift the focus!

My second approach is to take two or more of the competing tracks, say kick and bass, and play them together. No point in soloing one. EQ one while listening through it to the other. You may notice that you can subtract quite a bit from the bass without losing its character, but the kick’s punch is improved by the space you’re carving out. I do this a lot with vocals, too—focusing on the vocal inside a dense mix while subtracting from all the other stuff that’s stepping on it. When the lead just finds its home in its own uncongested space, you know you’ve got all the surrounding noise right.

author: peterlabberton
content: Anything much higher and you’re affecting a lot of lower mids, and I just wanted a sub boost

author: Deleted User
content:
1. Corrective EQ in the Upper midrange/high end, notching out all the harsh resonances, taming the pick transients if the bass is played with a pick. I love the way MAAT Santa Cruz does this ever so smoothly. 
2. I compress the bass with a compressor sidechained to a LPF(!), to get some low end body which is usually severely lacking. The LPF is set between 1000-2000 hz, attack 0-8 ms and release 200-400 ms depending on the tempo of the song/bass part. Reducing 3-5 dB on peaks. This gets me really far.
3. If the bass is a shortscale, I’ll use Goodhertz Tiltshift to move the low mids from around 200 hz to around 100 hz, out of the way of the guitars. 
4. Then I put an amp emulation on the channel. Whichever one floats your boat. Plugin Alliance B15, Guitar Rig, TSE BOD, whatever. I’ll be boosting low end and cutting high end here, or before with a separate instance of Tiltshift. 
5. If I want the bass to sound „rock“ and cut, I send it to a parallel distortion, which can be anything. I like TSE BOD, which is another sansamp copy which  has a lot of sub. My trick here is to add a clipper before the sansamp to really get extra gnarl. Logic‘s stock Bitcrusher works great, but I’m sure anything works.

author: cy (sigh)
content:
I have a full routing template including parallels, Inc ei get the files I'll organizettheninto their subgroups and everything gets routed. I just deleted the groups that don't end up with anything in them. I'm on S1 so it's easy to delete a lot of busses/channels in one go w a couple clicks. 

all my main sends are also setup but no actual plugins are loaded besides a clean gain plugin on my mixbus. I save my lost used chains/preset and I'll just drag them in as needed, I also delete the unused sends once I'm happy w the ones I got. as much as possible I duplicate the tracks and apply FX inline, makes exports so much easier. 

at this point I don't worry about getting my stem sound to be the same as the mix too much cause I try to get 90% if not more on the tracks themselves. my bus processing tends to be really really light. 

if a group works together I will do all edits I need to each element and just bounce the whole thing  as audio. I then disable and hide the old busses /channels, so I have a way to get back if ever needed.

out rn but I'll post a screenshot once I'm back on the desk.

author: Zach Hughes
content:
For me there are certain conditions that when met help facilitate forward motion / growth. These are somewhat in flux and my efforts and consistency in meeting these conditions wax and wan. For one, prioritizing my health. Hard to mix when your lower back is in constant pain because all you do is sit down all day. Getting better sleep. Drinking less booze. Eating healthier. Getting a gym membership, etc...

Another big one for me was getting out of debt and saving up an emergency fund. Hard to care for mix clients when you have constant FUD about finances.

I also think that mentorship plays a huge role. Not just you having a mentor but you mentoring others. Ideally at the same time. If you don't have an actual mentor you can substitute for some other authority you find online (i.e. puremix or mix for the masters subscription, participation in a discord with a bunch of audio Jedi, LWMR etc...). Not saying these are equal but better than nothing.

Then remaining curious and being willing to try new shit.

Lastly constantly trying to improve my monitoring situation. The ideal monitoring situation will perhaps always be a moving target. But I don't regret a single hour or dollar spent in pursuit of it.

author: Deleted User
content:
It’s also worth listening if it’s attack portion or the sustain that is getting buried. 

If there is not enough attack on the bass, you can sometimes trigger sample (percussive sample, sometimes a really short foley thing) that has the right presence area to have a little something that adds a punch to the bass. I often just copy one note that works into other parts that don’t cut through but this stuff only works sometimes. It doesn’t really work with busier bass parts

And sustain wise, compression can help when it’s done right or make it worse when it isn’t done right. Same with saturation. I think with sustain, there’s a lot of nuance in how you want the sustain to sit- performance is a huge part of this. Sometimes there’s too much bright stuff and it doesn’t allow the sustain to be audible, if you can tell something’s down there but you can’t really feel it or hear it that might be the issue. I noticed when there’s too much or wrong compression on other upper elements, it becomes an issue. 

Also dup the track and start new and see where you can take it, sometimes there’s too much going on and hard to track what’s causing what.

author: Adam Thein
content:
My two gotos are 

A) duplicate the track and pitch down an octave (Ableton), eq the hell out of it to fit, check phase against OG

B) perform/program a sub bass synth track that doubles the part exactly.  If you aren't a keyboardist maybe using Melodyne to extract midi or another audio-to-midi function

author: Ross Fortune
content:
Also probably worth saying that once you’ve got the part down, print both layers (soft or hard synth), as the phasing between each synth’s own oscillators can radically affect things (especially in the low end).

The relationship between the two layers will further exacerbate this (hence @Adam Thein ‘s comment re checking summed bass phase against each kick hit)

author: Ross Fortune
content:
If I'm totally rebalancing drums, I'll treat them as if I'm tracking them myself and building a basic working drum sound.This *usually* goes as follows, and I like to do it *very* quickly (as if the drummer is in the live room playing and everyone's waiting):

1. Mute everything.
2. Pull up kick in and out (+ sub or whatever they've recorded). Play with balance and phase of kick out until it feels good (good is context dependent - sometimes that's deep/subby/slow, sometimes that's punchy/percussive etc).
4. Bring up overheads along with kick mics. Flip overhead phase and play with balance til it sounds cool, or punchy, or whatever you're after. Sometimes there's a very obvious right or wrong answer, but often just figure out whatever works for the drum groove + arrangement + song. Where the bass sits can often help tell you what config will work best.
5. Solo snare mics, get them in phase with each other (just listen together and flip usually snare bottom until the blend sounds cool to you - often I'm looking for whichever configuration has more "thud", but that's context dependent). 
6.Unsolo and check snares against kicks and overheads. If you need to flip the snares, flip both top and bottom (or whatever combo) together so their relative phase remains intact. 
6. Add in rooms, again flipping and balancing til shit feels cool. Do same for crush mics, any other flavour stuff.

Toms are usually my last concern. Unless the groove is tom heavy, they might do only 2 or 3 hits across the whole song, so as Ryan said - hand gate those fuckers and deal with them once the general sound is dialled in.

author: Ross Fortune
content:
+1 on Trigger Gate from Ryan’s recommend.

The Oxford drum gate is also pretty unique in how you can have frequency dependent release - ie the fundamental of the snare can ring on longer, but the crack happens then disappears before the hihat wash becomes over exaggerated 

BX SSL 4k gate can be very precise (and in Fast mode you can use the “snap” as it opens as part of the sound), but I’m in the habit of creating separate gate trigger versions of the kick and snare - super heavily gated (and filtered + compressed) versions of the kick in and snare top. 

I commit the processing on those, mute them but then have them pre fade sending to SC Kick and SC Snare buses. Super handy for lots of functions - either very precise and malleable gate open and close on the audible drums themselves, but also for instrument sidechains, maybe Pro-MB ext input on a bass track, a sine generator under the kick / noise generator on snare, the Slate Trigger feeds etc. 

Having the gate triggers as audio allows you to slide them a couple samples back and forth as needed for groove or faux lookahead. 

Maybe there’s easier ways to do things (it’s a somewhat old school technique), but making them is one of my prep steps and they do get used in every session.

author: cian riordan
content:
1. I assume you’re talking about multiple mics/tracks of the same source and checking the phase relationship between? If so, I never do this. I’ll usually re-balance the two tracks I’m hearing so they’re equal volume before trying to make a decision.
2. Surely. It works well for transient rich stuff like drums… less so for guitars/basses/keys… etc.
3. Some folks manually adjust the track and it can get dangerous if you’re mismanaging your clips…. I find using a plugin is a more fool-proof way of making these adjustments. I used to just use the stock time-adjuster in Pro Tools but lately I’ve been using the Eventide Precision Time Align because it allows you to move forward and backwards, as well as course vs. micro adjustments.

author: BatMeckley
content:
Again (again again). This goes back to my whole argument about developing your taste. If you know what it’s supposed to sound like, it’s easy enough to get there. But some people just don’t understand why something works or doesn’t. And no amount of gear, or even you giving them the right thing, will make them change their mind. 

In this industry we’re essentially hired for our taste. You have to make an objective opinion about a subjective medium (this song is RIGHT. And DONE.) and then you have to see how it plays out. If you know what you’re doing it’ll work out more than it won’t, the only way to truly judge if you got it right is in hindsight. Hopefully with a big enough sample size you see some success, but if you don’t, I think it’s important to be honest and try to figure out where your taste might be wrong. (Ie: the producer mix ends up becoming a smash, what did we miss?). 
It’s best not to sweat individual songs TOO much. Try to look at your body of work as a whole.

Maybe im just not smart enough to pick out some problems with all 20khtz happening at the same time but it really helps me make decisions about balancing frequencies in a more intential way (kick and bass, what does the midrange actually sound like and what’s speaking, how are the top end of the vocal and hats/acoustics interacting) etc

author: Adam Thein
content: I like to reach for brighter verbs in this kind of scenario - something with some texture like a spring or a plate or a digital verb with some texture.  Start there, mess with the width of it first.  Generally think if it more as a synth pad layer.  Emphasizing 2-5k if it really needs to cut with spectre or Saturn or a brighter saturation.  Using a delay in combination so that the decay envelope has some movement so my ear latches onto it more.  Panning, modulation, tremolo, etc, subtle ways to grab attention even at low level.  And good old volume automation.  Printing the verb can help give you some visual feedback for how it’s decaying.

author: Ross Fortune
content:
What does floppy kick mean?

I had good luck with Smack Attack recently on a kick with excessively long low end that hung around after the hit.

Pushing the attack and lowering the overall gain in smack attack worked in that instance, but probably more important was high passing the drum bus so all the flubby stuff sub ~40/50Hz was minimised. I think the filter was somewhere around 60, probably at 12dB per octave. Might sound high in isolation, but it sat well with the bass.

author: Zach Hughes
content: Faraday is the most musical sounding limiter plugin I've found. Just as useful on individual elements as it is for bus work. The ratio defaults to 20:1 but you can change to 8:1 or 4:1. Honestly I would just fuck around with it and read the manual, it’s kind of intuitive but it’s also not a process I’ve seen well defined or explained by other resources. Celemony’s site has some walk through videos but YMMV with those. 

My adhd brain enjoys the game like process melodyne brings to the  “how can I get this vocal to sound the way I want” most effectively & efficiently, which is part of why I just enjoyed diving in without too much concern. The art of knowing when to split a note, snap it, leave it, etc is something that’s just gonna take time.

author: Marc
content:
For reference tracks — I was curious to compare two songs I love Bowie’s “Young Americans” and Springsteen “10th Avenue Freeze Out”. Similar instrumentation but the lesson for me was size and prominence of the different instruments. Bowie’s bass is way more prominent than Bruce. Bruce has the piano and guitar up front. Bowie’s has more delay and reverb. 

I think it reminds me I have to make more choices, and I also —(have to write better songs lol) — have to keep in mind when I use a reference track, that my tonal balance may be different or the vocal will sit differently if, say, my snare is way fatter/thinner than the reference track or my lead vocal is in a different octave register, which means the guitars are competing etc.

author: cian riordan
content: So to clarify, I will sometimes use HPF to solve for phase issues between multiple drums mics. The prime example of this is if I have a kit or a room mic that is in phase with the snare drum but out of phase with the kick drum. Sometimes, using the targeted phase shift of a HPF, you can find a way to get both fundamentals to pop into phase on the offending microphone.

author: Slow Hand
content:
Something short and roomy. It's almost always *Seventh Heaven*; either something from the *ambience* category or the *room* category.

If I pick an ambience patch I'll often play with going full-wetness and see what that gives me and then I'll balance the early reflections against the verb tail, usually ending up with much more ER's and less tail.

The goal is for something that's distinctly roomy, but doesn't have a long decay.

If you've got *Seventh Heaven* I'd also play with with the LFE slider to balance the subby component of the verb and make sure it's not muddying things up.

author: JakeTB
content:
Here’s the long-winded human version. We’re still on this learning journey so happy for any pushback or insight

For the most part, our group felt the tradeoffs of very subtle multiband often outweigh the benefits, since just putting those crossovers in the signal makes a bigger difference than, say, a dB of control.

We felt more liberal use of multiband can add an aggression and excitement that is very familiar and unique, and prefer treating it as a sweetener or energizer over the whole mix more than trying to control problem areas that could be addressed on tracks.

In the signal chain, its position can drastically effect how other tools behave. Up front, it can help a bus compressor or saturation device behave more predictably, but may mush things too much. Near the end, it allows those devices to play a more colorful role but may cause weird behavior when using fast, “transparent” limiters afterward. I like it first right now, most of our group like it near the end.

The hallmark signs of overuse for us were mixes that sound overly strident or when a vocal becomes inconsistent tonally from section to section as density changes.

Tools-wise, the group unanimously preferred minimum phase tools over linear phase or dynamic phase. OTT is a starting point, ear training to recognize that color. Once you hear it at 15-20%, you won’t be able to unhear it on many pop records. After ingraining that color, ML4000 and C4 both have their own flavors that can do a thing while offering tweakability when needed.

author: Jonathan Jetter
content: The thing w/ full program material is that different sounds have different pan positions. So adding S gain may effectively pan some sounds harder, but simultaneously create antiphase content from other sounds. You may gain more than you lose, if it's subjectively cool, then, cool. But like many things, it's easier to hear the benefits, takes a little longer to hear the downsides.

author: Mike Tierney
content: Damn we out here talkin about intonation systems? A lot of my bread and butter is contemporary classical/microtonal/experimental music and I'm in this world as both an engineer and often as a producer keeping track of how folks relate to the score and each other, take maps, etc. I tend to agree with some of the above that trying to chase down inharmonic relationships with EQ can make things worse, but I appreciate @LAPhill posting about bassoon/flute overtone series. @spectrummasters original question was about understanding the low mids and how they relate to EQing depending on the key; I think for me the way that understanding overtone series, tuning systems, and musical interactions in acoustic/orchestral instruments can relate to pop or rock mixing is like... Sometimes when I hear clashes between instruments playing thirds or clashes in the harmonic series and I'm trying to clear space in the mids/low mids, I do think about what instruments want to be occupying that space. So perhaps in the bassoon/flute example, I'd want the flute's fundamental to be stronger than the bassoon's first harmonic at C5, and that might look like EQing down the bassoon in the ranges of the flute's fundamentals, or in a rock mix looking at the bass's harmonics compared to where the lower range of the guitars are living. Obv instruments are moving and changing notes so none of this is surgical so much as the keys of the songs or the instruments' ranges might inform some general decisions about where to make space rather than just "cut 300 on the bass" or whatev

author: oaklandmatt
content:
Rather than thinking about "hacks," which imply secret shortcuts, I think the larger topic about how to listen *based on what you're doing* is a really interesting topic.

There are a lot of ways to think about it but one way is that listening/ getting perspective is different for me if I'm songwriting/producing vs mixing (vs occasionally-but-not-really-any-more mastering). 

When songwriting/ producing, I find it super useful to flip everything on its head often. I consistently use a wide variety of techniques to get out of the current place I'm in, in order to discover or channel some new thing into existence. In fact, doing new things is essential for my creative flow. So I'm always looking for new techniques or methods to try to disrupt my habits. I even prefer to not be in a perfect listening environment so I'm not lost in the sonics.

When mixing, I try to get almost completely out of that producer space and into a low volume, methodical, emotional and technical refining. Trying to make the production and songwriting ideas clear and impactful by manipulating individual things at a consistent volume in a consistent space (with great monitoring).

From what I understand from folks like @Nomograph Mastering, mastering is an even more focused version of that mentality. Trying to connect to and magnify with subtle touches the intention and emotional space of the record.

I also think that a lot of these things are personality based. It's part of the reason someone like me is still aggressively seeking the songwriting and production , while someone like Jon Castelli moved to mixing after producing for years, and someone like Ruairí has moved to mastering after doing what seems like every possible role in the music industry.

I realize this may be my producer personality perspective. I'm curious what other people who have been in the business a long time and played multiple roles feel. Especially those who have settled into something other than producing.

Ok so I was just talking to Beckley about how Pres that excel on bass often do on vocals as well, and vice versa. So I’ve been tryna dig deep on the 2254 and see if I can find an outboard version of it that will work for my studio. 

Kaplan got me onto using the 2254 on bass and the 33609 on BGVs & acoustics. (Apparently the 33609 was the breakout version of the compressor Neve invented and built for a slew of ABC consoles.)

Neve and RND et al are still riffing on that design, and it’s in the Shelford Channel now, and a few of their 500 series units (2264 & 535.)

author: onanisland
content:
yeah ive had it since it came out, same with soothe1 and all similar tools, @Joel "Roomie" Berghult was right. I tend to buy plugins to save time when projects come in. 

In the order I'd range these kind of tools mentioned here:

1. soothe
2. speccraft
3. reso and all others

If you have soothe, you're good imo. 

I liked this one (speccraft) because it gave me more control when I needed to chase a more targeted frequency without affecting the rest (i.e vocals, bass gtr, etc), stuff like that, but I use these kind of tools sparingly. cymbals, egtrs cabs, things like that, almost never on the mixbus because IMHO (don't shoot me), soothe-like tools, affect too much of the signal - suppressing resonances/frequencies "killing the depth" because of the pushing down of reverbs, delays, etc. That is not to say I never use it, there are times for everything, and every tool has its place but yeah. There are people who use it that way and still get GREAT results.
As much as I want to simplify my workflow, 90% of the job is audio janitorial, I go back to simple eq, compression, fader...

I saw another comment asking about Spiff > I don't know if anybody wanted my input on that but nevertheless - I like it sometimes on drums after tape-sims where it kills too much of the transients if I need to drive it more for *reasons* but the sound is lovely (i.e country), bit of spiff after and get best of borth worlds.

author: Chris Lyon
content:
Try OTT on your instrument bus then “sidechain” after it. And by sidechain I mean shaperbox, kickstart lfotool, not traditional sidechaining. You basically create a wall of sound then add dynamics back in but fully under your control. Use the shape of the sidechain to add groove. 

Sidechain all your verbs too and even try subtle sidechaining on the vocals especially in the “drop”

author: SoundsLikeJoe
content: Whenever I think there's an unpleasant "chirp" in anything,  I create a tight Q band and boost the signal a ridiculous amount (get the eq filter to resonate subtly at the added frequency).  Sweep it up and down until the chirp is amplified more. Once you hear that obnoxiuos sound louder you'll know it.  Then invert the positve gain to a step notch filter.  That way you're not cutting a region. You're cutting the specific pitch of the chirp. Keep all the good of the click. Remove just the bad tone. That's what helps me in these situations anyway.

author: ALXCPH
content:
This is over simplified but.
If you want “loud 808s” it’s all about levelling everything around it. Clipping your drums for a “loud” impact but low peak level.
Thin out your instruments/loops to make it seem like the bass is bigger than it is when it comes in. Because a bunch of the low mids will come from the 808. 
Saturation and clipping is your friend here.

author: Josh Bowman
content:
For rock and folk music I generally just do subgroups like drums, bass, guitars, leads, bvs, lvs. For pop oriented songs generally more split out/ kick, snr, toms, hats, cymbals, fx, different synths split out etc. i just use soundflow scripts that solo and bounce what I tell it to and run it at night or at lunch. Freezing tracks first can make it go way faster. As for mixbuss, I take off my final limiter (or turn down the input, however the song was sent to mastering)… I’m usually not compressing the buss hard enough for it to matter. Sometimes the sum of the stems ends up sounding better than the mix! Generally people are using them for their MD to create a live show, or for dance remixes etc. For sync most people seem happy with instrumental and accapella in my experience so far?  Also if your trying to key your mix buss compressor from a printed mix, freezing most of the session first (besides fx etc and aux tracks) seems to help the side chain feel pretty close to what the mix was. I don’t bother with it though most of the time as I’m doing a couple db at most on the buss comp.

Edit: one other idea I’ve messed with pre soundflow, is, if your just doing subgroups and have the routing setup, save your mixbuss as a track preset and when your ready to print recall it on all your masters and commit the tracks. It works for me unless im using too much uad etc.

author: Maxim
content:
“The sound quality was as good as anything available, but benchmark analog still had an edge. So, we added a radical new tech to thEQblue. It’s called FiDef and it adds that indescribable beauty lent by the best of analog.

FiDef by FideliQuest is a very low amplitude, psychoacoustic stimulus designed specifically for audio engineers. FiDef can be thought of as dither for your brain. It makes a receptive brain relax and pay closer attention to an incoming audio stimulus. In brain physiology laboratory tests using functional neuroimaging techniques, FiDef has proven to excite brain activity related to perception and attention, and to enhance the subjective processes of listening and engagement.”

Sounds interesting but it seems only to affect the listening experience. Sounds processed equally still null regardless.

author: sethearnest
content:
I use layouts to get my sub groups or VCAs or Folders to populate the S1s. You can program those soft keys at the bottom as layouts. So in my world, the first button is just all the tracks in the session. Button two shows only my Folder sub groups (Drums, Perc, Gtrs, etc) so that’s my go to for that. Button three would be showing only VCAs on the S1, etc. 

So layouts are great once you get them programmed into your template. They save with the session, however, so if you get in a PT session from someone else, your layouts won’t be there. You can save them into your template(s) though, then they’ll always be there for those sessions.

author: Calvin Lauber
content: I stole this from Shawn Everett but, try monitoring at just a low enough level that you can hear some sub 100hz  info, and try soling eveything around 150 and below on your master channel. Just listen to how the bass and kick are hitting, you can tell if they sound cluttered and swampy or if they are working together. Generally I like the kick feeling big and clear in the lower frequencies and the bass having plenty of clarity and body in the upper low end. Doesn’t work as well if you crank your speakers in a wonky room

author: jantrit
content: A lot of the time I will mess with hard panning diff mono sources in a mix to create the sense of width whilst maintaining balance. Also if it is double tracks like others have said I like to sit them in diff places tonally or treat them differently (diff verbs or pushing diff eq points) it’s the differences in the hard panned sources that create width. When tonally different information reaches each ear at the same time your brain tells you it’s wide! When it’s only subtlety different like in the case of doubles it can end up sounding mono again. A lot of the time I like to pick two elements that are holding it down throughout the track (maybe guitar and Rhodes) and then hard pan those in opposite directions. This maintains the balance left to right.  So I guess try hard panning a mono element and then balancing it out with a totally different mono element the other side.

By fundamentals I mean that a lot of this is about communication with the artist and figuring out what’s essential to them, or else how can you gain stage the good stuff? You gotta A/B the roughs and your refs a lot and make moves that are more decisive than super nitpicky too (be as detailed as necessary but be conscious that you don’t have to make this sound pop pretty). I remember I sent a mix to have @Rollmottle check out a couple months that wasn’t hyper-pop but I needed to go back and add in the grit of the bass actually pumping my final limiter cause it gave the mix life.

author: NoahNeedleman
content:
I’ve got some ideas for you. 
1) if your gain staging is done properly, you’ll notice when the low end starts to interact negatively with the rest of the frequency bands. 
2) reference reference reference. Listen to songs with the kind of low-end you’re looking for and reference them diligently.
3) have someone you trust that can tell you how it’s going when you think you’re getting close. I got a road rig together for mixing, expecting that I’d get 70% there before finishing in my studio. Surprisingly I got closer to 95% just using good techniques ¯\_(ツ)_/¯ 
4) its like anything else, the more you do it, the better you get at it. 

I hope this helps. Andrew Scheps is on headphones now and he seems to be real happy. You might be able to find some good insight from him.

Also keep in mind I do mostly Country Music and bedroom pop, which aren’t necessarily the most bass heavy genres.

author: ALXCPH
content:
That is true, but I think a good mix still sounds bad in target 😅 and I’ve been in enough bars and restaurants that have playback systems that sound worse than my iPhone in a bathroom only playing out the left speaker. 

And people will still say, “omg I love this song” and start bouncing their head.

 I believe that great songs translate every and anywhere. But fidelity cannot IMO be appreciated in these specific places. 

Ofc there are exceptions. But try eating at a restaurant on a beach promenade in south Spain and the restaurant next to you has a speaker 20 inches from your head blasting a different song. And tell me you think the vocal is warm or the drums are punchy. I think, sadly for general non music fans what they find in music, is less quiteness it’s not even about the song. 

Whereas I think the people who enjoy music, will appreciate that extra punchy drum sound or warm vocal and deep bass. And I believe those people use headphones 80% of the time. They might have a great speaker system at home. But how much time do we really have at home listening to said speakers? Headphones are with us on the go all the time. Everyone I know under 30. Listens primarily on headphones. Or their iPhone speaker. Sometimes a JBL at the beach or park, and every now and then a party speaker at a party while drunk. The ones who really really love music, either have an old vintage speaker set from their parents or a Sonnos/smart speaker type thing. 

I still believe mixing for speakers is important, and @Nomograph Mastering has a great point in speakers translating to headphones easier than vice versa. But I always make sure shit sounds amazing on my AirPods. I’d rather sacrifice something in the speaker than the AirPods. But then again. I don’t have the accolades you do. So I might be shooting myself in the foot. But that is my general philosophy.

author: Ross Fortune
content:
Come on dude, there's a reason this type of misleading promotional pricing is ruled illegal - at least in the UK.

I'm sure we're all savvy enough in here to understand that marketers earn their wage by exploiting weaknesses (widely documented and scientifically substantiated) in human psychology. The felt urgency created by countdown timers and sale price indicators ("normal" prices slashed out, bold colours advertising "temporary - don't miss this" pricing etc) causes consumers to make irrational decisions and hurriedly complete purchases they otherwise wouldn't have made. I guarantee everyone in here has felt those psychological pulls. I think that satisfies the definition of predatory.

I was generally aware of rulings here, but looked into examples before posting, so here you go (https://www.asa.org.uk/advice-online/promotional-savings-claims.html):


*"Ads for a mattress sale which stated ““HALF PRICE”, alongside a box with numbers counting down from £399 to £199 were ruled against by the ASA. Over the previous year, the mattress was shown at the higher price for 49.85% of the year, and at the lower price for 50.14%, and the price had alternated between the two each month. Because the promotional periods were essentially equivalent in length to the periods when the full price was charged, the ASA did not consider that higher price was the  established usual selling price (Dormeo UK Ltd, 13 October 2021). Similarly, complaints were received about a sale for Simba mattresses.  The advertiser did not provide the ASA with any pricing history to demonstrate that the usual selling price was genuine, however, the complainant provided screenshots which demonstrated that the reference price of the product had fluctuated over a three-month period, and that the mattress had been on sale for 71% of the year. Therefore, the complaints were upheld (Simba Sleep Ltd, 21 September 2022). See also J Sainsbury plc, 06 June 2018."*

author: Ross Fortune
content:
With just three tracks I’d be too analytical for that clever approach 👆🏻

I’d run versions of each track with all methods available and have them on playlists. Some methods work better for different types of material, different frequency content, different transient preservation… 

I’d do the grunt work then flip between playlists until I got everything feeling the best it could. Eg a lot of times RX sounds “smoothest” on stereo material with high end content, but soundshifter parametric in sync mode can sound garbly and subtly artefacty, but retains or even sometimes adds a vibe. 

Suck it and see.

author: stefanmacc
content: If you have a lot of transients happening then try using subtle distortion on the close mics . That same lo fi plug-in can work somewhere between .1 and 2 db of gain.. that will even things out quite a bit. I do multiple layers of parallel chains on my drum busses… vca compressors with a fast release are fun for this

author: BatMeckley
content:
It’s always been: if something is crucial to the vibe of the song, say a certain echo, or dotted stereo delay guitar part, that shit gets printed and sent as an option. But the mixer also gets the rough in case they got a better way to do it. 

That’s why a mixer gets a rough bounce. So they know what to reference. 

CLA used to have a 12 page mix submission requirement thing where you had to consolidate all files, take off all fx entirely, and send him all the tracks bounced from 1 clearly labeled.

Again, it’s CRAZY to me watching a mixer pushback against having to actually mix the song. It’s like someone hiring me to vocal produce and I’m like “cool, but you have to pre record the vocals, compress them right, get the takes, comp em, mix them, and then I’ll… tickle them a little. Where’s my 5k and a point?”

author: JustinLeu
content: I really don't want to get in the weeds on anything....if you don't think this is a good use of someones time to look at, feel free to delete this 👍  The only point I was trying to make is that there is a lot contributing to how frequencies add up. The "absolute" relationship between all microphones recording one drum will remain the same. Where things can get more complex is when drums are flaming...sometimes they add up in a pleasing way, sometimes they don't. When  the kick starts slightly ahead of the snare or vice verca it just adds up differently right? Live drums make complex tones and depending on the hit even the tone/pitch slightly changes. Lining up the hits (fixing the flams however you can make it work) changes the phase relationship. The most common thing I do is replace with a good (all lined up) hit when I can, or line them up. The phase flip mostly is done with bass notes (for me), but I 100% have found it to be a solution for some weird drum hit before....I attached a screen capture of some flams (from a really sloppy ccm recording)  just to help illustrate the potential problem.

author: Edward Rivera

author: JustinLeu
content: In my experience you can open up RX-Mouth de-click, RX-de-click (I have my default to multiband mode), and an instance of pro-q3 audio-suite with a HP filter around 200hz on “A” and then flip to “B” and set it to the HP filter and a low-shelf around 800-1K subtracting -8 with the output knob set to -10. I listen to the vocal without fx, but with comp/eq somewhere around what it might be in the mix. Make a new playlist then edit clicks/pops with the RX-tools and plosives with “A” setting on pro-q. The “B” setting I described will be used to clean up breaths that have annoying frequency build up or “s” sounds that maybe not be recorded the best…I’ll change those settings to make it fit what ever I need to. This does not take long to do and sometimes I will use mouth-de click on the whole audio file with a gentle setting to start.

author: Jonathan Jetter
content: If you match the output level, boosts are cuts and cuts are boosts, and it becomes a question of workflow. If there's dynamic or harmonic processing downstream, then it's about pushing harder into the processing vs. pushing less hard, and that's of course a choice to make. Some EQs (e.g. API) perhaps lend themselves to additive work because the proportional Q is super wide at +-2dB and sometimes people think of subtractive EQ as a tool for more narrow resonance notching, and it's a bit unfamiliar to have -2dB with a Q of 0.5 or whatever.

author: Calvin Lauber
content: I really like referencing. I get pretty inspired when I hear a rough mix and then recall a record I love that I feel would be a good influence on, for instance, how the low end feels or the way the drums hit. The big thing I’ve learned is just once you’ve built the mix, at a certain point you have to zoom out and get away from referencing anything for a while. It can be easy to mix in circles with too much back and forth. But early on in the process it’s really helpful for me

author: Jonathan Jetter
content: This might not be the most helpful answer but I think you have to start by being able to hear the full spectrum in stereo. If your speakers don't reach far down into the bass, and/or if you're summing to a mono sub, how can you make decisions on stereo content in the lows vs. the low mids?

author: Jonathan Jetter
content: And while we're less sensitive to directionality in a low frequency signal I do think the phase interaction between differences in L + R LF content is clearly audible, and sometimes crucially important to certain sounds. I really do find the LF Side high-pass / mono-making thing is often quite a compromise. And, both widening + narrowing via M/S will often have unintended effects on the overall image. Things that were hard panned now won't be, etc.

author: Rob Domos
content:
Some other things you can to create space for them each to sit:

- Move one of them to the sides with something like the stereoize function in the ozone imager. Even just one band wider on one of them could solve the problem. 

- Try something like ST4B to get a different relationship between the transients and sustains of the sounds 

- If all else fails, I sometimes try out a *very* slight tremolo on sustained sounds and it surprisingly consistently cleans up cloudy masking issues. The way I do it the tremolo isn’t noticeable but it still creates a hair more space for the other sounds to pop through. I usually only do this on reverbs and pads, but it *might* work on one of the basses.

author: Rob Domos
content: Another thought I just had: moving the various bass sounds left and right a few ms can help a ton. It can help transients not step on one another so they can all come through clearer and it can help the the sounds lock together more phase wise, especially if they’re often on the same note as one another and they’re played consistently (as midi synths usually are)

author: BatMeckley
content:
What’s the synth bass doing in the context of the song. What are you not getting from it that you felt the need to add subsonic information beneath it. What were you hoping to accomplish with both parts? What’s the tempo of the song? Is it meant for the .5% of people that have full range systems that can hear 60hz let alone 30hz accurately? Or is it for Spotify and you were just hoping to have no headroom? 

The answers to the why usually leads us to solutions.

author: Zach Hughes
content: I recently revisited a mix I initially did in 2021 for an as of yet unreleased project. A folk / rock / americana track. My OG mix had this really aggressive edge to it that I kinda liked but it also felt way too scooped in the low mids. I checked out my old session and turns out I had cranked a ton of 8khz on the mixbus (a move I haven't felt compelled to do since 2021). Related I've been really enjoying thick / dense / full bodied mixes that still have excitement / edge up top especially for vocals and I had previously struggled to achieve a similar 'heft' in my own mixes compared to what I was hearing. I think in the past I was too quick to zap low mid resonances in my vocals / guitars. So I've been experimenting cutting less down around 200hz-600hz and emphasizing more. But then I felt I was losing some of that edge / excitement by see-sawing too much with the low mids relative to up top. I've found cutting some 170hz clears much of that up for me (like oh hey there's my snare or more room for kick / bass), I achieve the thickness above in that 200-600hz range and balance that with the excitement around ~8khz. Pushing and pulling.

author: Deleted User
content:
I love midrange mess. 

having good amount of midrange to poke out is the right idea. It just needs to be distributed in a way that makes sense to our ears. 

Low and high end lacking could mean that there’s actually not enough of them, but it could also mean that the midrange isn’t distributed in a way that lets the low end be pushing the speakers and be able to hear the top end *distinctively. 

In terms of midrange distribution, I found it helpful to think about “where do I want this instrument to occupy in the mids?” -> to do this, context is absolutely necessary. I’m not a mixer, but I like to produce with that in mind, and once I get to the mixing process then I listen to the whole thing and start thinking about where I want to put things. 

and then there is this new thing I’m starting to find and explore- “what instruments want to push the speakers together in xHz area?” 

sometimes boosting the same area in two different elements that hit simultaneously help tighten things up and glue things together, rather than everything moving front and back all over the place. 

I used to think everything has to be separated like a jigsaw puzzle, but I’m only starting to realize that not how audio works. these days I’m learning that some things will want to occupy the presence in the same or similar area, and that is the thing that helps the mixes feel more coherent sometimes.

author: Ross Fortune
content:
Warmth

Alters the frequency-dependant characteristics of the limiter’s detector circuit.

A big part of Faraday Limiter’s thick, punchy sound is its frequency-dependent gain reduction. Low and high frequency sounds hit the limiter differently, and — depending on the Warmth setting — will exhibit different attack/release characteristics. High values, such as 100%, generally sound thicker and punchier, while low values, like -100%, have a quick, bright limiter sound.

For example, you can often use the warmth control to emphasize different aspects of a snare drum: more Warmth gives more thud & low end; less Warmth gives more stick & snare presence.

The Warmth control is not EQ, and will not change the frequency response of the plugin.

author: cian riordan
content: With bass guitar, it's usually more effective to mess with the timing between a DI track and an amp recording than it is to mess with filters.

author: cian riordan
content: There will always be a phase interaction if you have two parallel processing chains on a single source. In the case of the amp, there's a physical delay in the sound coming out of the speaker and hitting the microphone. In the case of an amp sim, there's just so many variables there (if its trying to replicate that physical delay, delay compensation, etc). Best to just check that stuff with a phase switch though. I wouldn't dig too much into this HPF idea... it's really solving for a different problem.

author: Matt Huber
content:
I would start by listening for un-musical resonances in the guitars. 

Also, if I feel like carving a certain section feels like it’s taking things too far and can’t find the balance, sometimes it’s helpful to dig into the toolbox for something that isn’t static 

Example: guitar feels like it’s stepping on bass. Remove low end now guitar feels thin. I’d reach for soothe or a multiband comp and sidechain it to the bass so that only the bass fundamental is being ducked out of the guitar. Aka, a more focused, dynamic carving

author: Colin Althaus
content:
I’ve found this often has to do with phase artifacts in M-S processing causing the image to sum together in odd ways (sometimes even ending up on the opposite side!)

Think of M-S processing like algebra. When converting left-right to mid-side (which is really sum-difference):

M = L + R
S = L - R

To reconstruct L and R,
L = 0.5(M + S)
R = 0.5(M - S)

So whether something appears on L or R is determined by its phase relationship on the S channel (+S or -S) relative to the M channel.

Flip the polarity of the whole S channel (+S to -S) and the whole image reverses: L becomes R, and R becomes L.

Now imagine a steep filter like a 24dB/oct HPF… here is a screenshot of the measured phase response. At the corner frequency of 100Hz we see the signal is 180 degrees out of phase.

author: Slow Hand
content:
I find it's rarely necessary to compress a synthesizer if you're the one programming it. You already have control over the attack/sustain ratio on the instrument using the ADSR controls. And you can balance the harmonics through your choice of filtering or oscillators. Synthesizers rarely have low-level information to be revealed that can't simply be turned up at the source.

Of course, you might want the distortion artifacts from compression, but I'd probably use a saturator module.

That said, if you're a mixer who has received an audio bounce of a synth, then... sure! Compression would be good for balancing poke-y stuff, controlling boomy low-end, or there could be some room tone from a re-amp signal, or some attack that needs to be accentuated. So compress away!

author: LAPhill
content: I wouldn't think of it that way, unless the partials are really, really prominent. The first few harmonics can layer up to make a pronounced 5th or octave that's stronger than the sum of its parts, which can have unintended consequences. Like the 5th an octave higher on a power chord interacting with something on a bass note an octave lower. Sounds great until you have, say, a third instead of an octave between the guitar and bass. Suddenly your overtones are interacting in non-musical ways that usually create an unpleasant and out of tune smearing right where you want musical harmony to speak clearly. Again, all of this can be used with intention.

author: JustinLeu
content:
Things I would try:
-Hit a ref track A/B
-Mute an element of the mix (sometimes muting the thing you were hyper focused on for a minute works great!)
-Change monitoring (I will flip to auratones frequently when doing level balances)
-Change to my monitor “dim” setting

Normally a small amount of time doing any of the above will get me sorted quickly.

Not necessarily related to hyper focused but something that seems to get me to the finish line more quickly…mix with the bass muted for a bit, balance all that midrange goodness and get it dialed, then bring up the bass to fill it out. Helps me not swamp stuff with bass. Same thing with drums…a lot of the time I find I am mixing with the drums too hot/punchy so towards the end of the mix I will see what happens if I go down -2db or so…sometimes that makes the mix feel perfect.

author: Slow Hand
content:
The first thing that comes to mind is that you may be pushing into your master buss limiter too hard. 

How much gain reduction is your limiter currently doing? If you're already pushing aggressively into your limiter and then you're boosting low end *into* it, it's going to keep turning it back down.

If that's what's happening, the answer would be to back off your limiter so that the low end doesn't get compressed.

author: Slow Hand
content:
Ok. Trying this out.  I'm not gonna be as thorough this time, because that's a lot of variables to document with photos. So I'll give you my general observations and y'all can take me at my word.

I dropped the input signal to -20dB and then played around with boosting at 100Hz (where my test tone is) to see if the harmonics were different for different EQ band types. I tried a *bell*, a *low shelf*, and a *tilt shelf* to boost.

I was able to boost it +16dB in both *subtle* and *warm* mode before I got any of that harmonic breakup that we started to see in my previous tests as we got approached -0.03 dB. It appears that distortion on *subtle* mode (once again) doesn't kick in at all until the output signal gets within -4dB of 0dB on the output meter. The *amount* I boosted did not matter. The distortion only came when the signal crept close to 0 on the output meter.

All three band types appeared to behave the same when it came to harmonic bloom.
### tl;dr:
I did not detect any difference in behavior with different EQ band types. So they appear to behave the same. It's looking like the breakup doesn't kick in until the output level of the signal is within -4dB of 0dB on the output meter. *Then* they start to break up.

The only exception is the 1st order harmonic at -22dB that appears as soon as you enable *warm* mode. That's always present, no matter how hard you're driving it.

author: Slow Hand
content:
I tried that. I did see a *little* bit of variation, but it was subtle. Here are the two big observations:
### Subtle and Warm Mode
@ -0.03 input level, the harmonic bloom diminishes in amplitude as I sweep my test tone from 30 Hz (complex bloom) up to 4 kHz (totally gone). So it seems that the transfer curve is biased to break up in the low end sooner and you have to drive it *way* harder to get bloom after 2kHz.
### Warm Mode only
The 1st order harmonic seems to gradually drop 6dB in amplitude as I sweep my test tone from 30 Hz up to 1.8 kHz. It's still present after that, but it stops dropping in amplitude.

author: Deleted User
content: Loudness question: I’ve been struggling with drum samples and bass/808s specifically. A lot of these sounds come in so dense and compressed, they sound good in level close to 0dbfs but they don’t have the knock and energy they had when they are turned down to create headroom. Especially when it’s playing with other instruments that are more dynamic. A lot of times they even sound smaller and thinner too. So I’ve attempted using samples that have taller peaks but at the end of the day I end up doing similar treatments (distortion, clipping) to get the level of density and aggression. Which also leads to another question about transient treatments. I’ve watched tutorials on this topic and some people used clipper to have the limiter work less, and the others work slightly differently by preserving the peak and using parallel to create density. I tried both ways, but still left me with the issue of not being able to crank it louder without messing things up. With the dense drum samples, the rest of the mix would start choking every time the drums hit. Generally I find it so much easier to get things to compelling loudness when there’s no drum instrument (I find percussive elements with higher pitches easier to fit in the mix). How can I work around this?

author: kidcutler
content: I’ve got a drum bus, bass bus (sub), vox dry, vox wet, music bus (sample/synths etc), those feed into an all vox, drum/bass & music (3 buses), then those 3 feed the master. Those 3 get saturate each, barely hitting but a nice “escape hatch” if i need more or less push/grit at the end. Then the mix bus has a similar layout to castelli’s, I really don’t do shit on the mix bus but push the tracks clipper

author: Zack Hames
content:
Do you have a really transparent DI ala Avalon U5 and a short, low capacitance cable? 

I find that the transformers in most DI inputs and long cables are what ruin “clear” DI tones through amp sims. 

If you’ve got that all covered, I usually just do a dip around 300 or so to taste, nothing crazy. Maybe HPF at 80 or so, depending. Im sure you’ve tried this before though.

author: cy (sigh)
content:
0.1 is a percentage as far as i know. The actual amount of saturation deoends both on that the mix knob and the og sources inherent Harmonics that get excited. 

That same amount ona heavy bass won't saturate the same as ona soft flute for example (also depends on the freq  range)

That said I know a lot of mixers that swear by the warm mode on the exciter for even Harmonics And they are very subtle w it.

The eq idk. I'll never really used it but similarly I know a lot of mixers that swear by it. If there's really that much of a difference it's either 1. That's how it is on the eq that it's trying to emulate- it's a vintage style eq, I don't think it's meant to be linear in any way. 

2. There's something wrong w the plug and I'd suggest hitting up support about it.

author: bobby k
content: man I need some advice here. got paid up front to mix an album and it's taken over a year to complete, just feeling not worth it anymore. The issue we keep running in to is really terrible engineering and production caked into the vocals by this very large/random span of producer (14 total songs), then the artist says that every vocal feels over compressed (I can assure you that none of it is coming from me). I've told her time and time again that perhaps these notes would have been more effective during production or recording, but it still feels like it's my fault. (also, fun tidbit: her verbage is "the eq on the vocal feels too compressed"). she references the mixes on very old Apple earbuds and has the most ludacris notes about the bass n stuff. I'm mixing on PMC IB1s and Airpods, FWIW. just feels like this endless uphill battle where I'm worried I'm running thin on patience.

author: bobby k
content: Yup, I've talked on the phone with a couple friends and it feels very clear I need to walk away. I think the way you explained it though was super helpful; that the boundaries were exceeded and I'm unable to continue. We actually do have a contract, but it quite literally has 1 sentence detailing the mixing responsibilities...the rest is about points on a production I finished for her over a year ago. SO WEIRD that this contract represents both things?? Anyways, the consensus I've come to is to pull out the calculator and figure out what my "kill fee" is for the amount of work I've done already, then subtract that from the flat fee I got upfront for mixing (7 out of 13 mixes are approved). The valuable lesson I've learned here is: A. the artist has to like their own music (I just don't think this is true with her...lots of insecurities). B. the artist has to like what I do (again I don't know where I'm going wrong, but she seems to think mixing can save a song). C. I have to like the music (I don't, and I haven't from the beginning). I think all 3 of these points are valuable before committing to a full album.

author: itaylerner
content: I feel all of this as well, super eager to hear what other people’s thoughts are! What I’ve landed on is creating an aux with the verb / space that I want the mix to exist in, and then I carefully dial in what’s getting sent there. So each individual group aux (drums, music, vocals, low end) will each have a send to their own aux where they get some eq, mostly just filtering, and then they get sent from there to the “global verb.” Hope that makes sense haha. That’s been the most effective way for me to get those natural sounding reflections that make it feel alive without adding the business I get from just slapping a verb on the master.

author: Zack Hames
content:
Because everything else in the mix is perceptively / relatively louder. 

Like when you scoop the mids on a sound. There is perceptively more bass and treble, right? You could turn up the overall mix and have it bump without the harshness of high mids. Hopefully that makes sense. 

You’re not wrong, it is confusing and maybe someone else has a better answer.

author: spectrummasters
content:
hi gents, thanks for picking up on my question, much appreciated. i fully agree with the statement that it seems a really counter-intuitive idea at first.....ive not really started using it as a method yet.....having only just heard about it. @Eric Martin thanks for your technical reply, and @oaklandmatt hi mate, i remember you discussed in the last episode about cutting low mids and yes, i saw jon putting it in the mids yesterday to good effect, but I didnt notice him using it in the high mids. (i'll rewatch when they post it back up)  Its this cutting / scooping of the high mids (up at c.1-6khz) that ive never heard much about before, Im interested because i dont like crushing my mixes to get a higher lufs and if this is an effective way to get their smoothly im v interested in learning more....im happiest with my mixes at -12 lufs but will push to -9 ....but id like to get to -9 with as little sacrifice to the fidelity and low end as poss.
Ive also heard recently (I think i heard it from colin leanord talking) something about the trap guys always scooping out the  second octave harmonic   of the bass ? c. the 110-130hz region....Is anyone familiar with using this? (eg.  the  "missing fundamental" and all that good stuff)

author: spectrummasters
content: thanks for your reply man, i get you about the relativity of the different ranges of the mix and how it effects our perception, but im still a little baffled, because id figured that if you lower the high mids AND consequently appear to bring up the low end .....id have thought that low end would still be hitting the limiter the same way as before, but now you have less mix information in the range we are most sensitive to...so it will seem quieter for the same lufs......but im aware that this is NOT the case accoridng to mastering engineers....there must be some interplay where the lufs measuring system can be tricked by this technique ? (its confusing). @Eric Martin  Im going to have to hunt some info down re: Lufs weighting and the algorithm to learn how to manipulate this approach i guess

author: spectrummasters
Eric Martin
content:
right, there was a spectral shaper on low mids on one of his buses, but then again on the mix bus it was doing the 1-6k.

I think from what I understand that JC is doing he is controlling the attack so it’s consistent, then using the transient shaper to make sure it’s the same for every hit. It is smart, and for his workflow it’s also fast and easy.

I use compressors a lot, but I’m also working in mostly indie rock with acoustic drums and bass guitars not 808’s and drum machines, which is a drastically different world. I also think I’m doing what most people don’t do and I don’t always love the artifacts of compression so I generally use slow attacks to maintain transients and fast releases to recover quickly (I adjust so that I get the fastest release before audible distortion)

BTW Bruce Swedien while he may have evangelized not using compression don’t underestimate that his greatest works were done to tape and even when you were conservative and didn’t hit tape hard, the transformers going into tape and out of and the tape as a medium itself would peak limit attack heavy instruments like drums

author: spectrummasters
content:
i hear ya , re: 808 through a neve pre-amp, spot on agree with you. thats exactly what i do ....defo the sauce  ! lol. I sum OTB and send my drums , vox , fx and music buses through my ssl sixes (no transformers, no phase shifting , lovely SSL punch and transient response) and then bass through the 73 and into the SSL on an insert return bypassing their pre....I came by that one from an old Jaycen Joshua tip ! 

I also find i use the neves transformers if ive got a phase issue between two parrallels, if i send one through the neve it can often shift the phase in one a bit and they blend better when they sum back after. This realisation led me into learning about phase rotation and all pass filters this year......im still deep diving phase since christmas lol 

I’d defo recommend SSl X-phase plug in to anyone ITB 

What you say about tape is interesting to me because.....

i wonder if the "to tape sound" will soon be a thing of the past even as an  aesthetic.....the artists in my genre, here in london and i know its the same in the states......their new forward looking aesthetic is this ruined/ultra smashed/clipped 808 , hi-passed percussion , serum synths and a  filtered vocal sound....ts like distorted nintendo on acid .....lol i actually like doing tracks like that for the madness of it....but magnetic flux and tape hysterisis are a v distant memory at that point me thinks......

author: ehutton21
content:
i just realized that i believe we’re talking about two different plugins! im using lift 3, I believe diamond transient is the one with the ability to clip in the mid range. i don’t have transient, but after my experience with using these across my mixes I’m pretty set on adding it to my arsenal. diamond lift 3 sounds big and powerful on bus and mastering duties. there’s a certain heft it adds in the clipping department that my other tools don’t have, but it’s compression and eq moves are actually quite versatile—it can be just as powerful but also surprisingly… musical?

i like compressor mode 3, clipped mode 1, and i gain stage the bus/track so i can drive the input on the plug-in, compress 1-2 db, drive the makeup gain of the compressor into the clipper so i’m on the verge of hitting the overs, then i gain match the plug-in to desired level. maybe add a little saturation there too. it’s got a subtle feel but it’s 👌🏼

my experience with this has been incredible with it on drum bus, music bus (albeit i’m not clipping), and mix bus especially when i get to the stem stage of my work in ableton (i do some stem work in ableton after doing the heavy lifting stuff in protools). pure insanity. 

i’m pretty disappointed that even with my mac m1 studio, acustica plugins in protools aren’t really running for me. gonna have to troubleshoot that.

content:
Hey y’all I know it’s a big point of contention when printing stems, whether to use a stereo bounce of your mix to side chain your 2-bus limiter. But what about subgroups?

In my production routing I’ve got subgroups for drums bass guitar synth vox etc. So say I’m bouncing stems for my mix engineer. The drum stems they get aren’t gonna add up to what I’m hearing right? Because they’re going to hit my drum bus compressor one by one?

I think a good example is Disclosure sending Jon the stems for Talk. Guy always has a drum bus with Oxford Inflator, Saturn 2, and an API-2500. But when Jon gets the stems the drums are going to be individually compressed and thus not what Guy was actually hearing right?

same process just sending the channels to an aux pre-fader at the same  levels /panning and having that aux be the sidecían to the subgroup.  Solo the channel you need  

(and mute it's send while you exp that channel - otherwise the channel would be send twice) 

for that Disclosure song, think I remember him mentioning  he recreated that processing but more to his taste/liking

content:
I love this topic. Great question @chloe corley! 
All the ideas here are things that have worked for me, esp on the tracking side.
But I do you wideners too. Ozone Imager works really well for me on sources that are already stereo. 
Also, something that really helps me, is using fx to widen. Taking a stereo delay and using it in Multi-Mono (this also works with eq,) and plugs like Primal Tap and Crystalizer. 
Last year I went deep into the stereo field, and the biggest thing i learned is that the only things in the middle should be kik snr bass & vocals, then everything else on the sides!

author: ehutton21
content:
To @ALXCPH’s point, I think it’s important to understand that hyper pop is all over the map and the kids making it usually started in their bedrooms and because they grew up in such a widespread era in the early 2000s & 2010s, hyper pop can really sound like *anything*. It can be beautiful guitar ballads with lots of stacks, or it can be insane berzerk bass with crazy vocal effects. Brevin Kim is a duo that embody that balance very well. 

In the way it’s create, hyperpop borrows from and feels reminiscent of the punk days because of how connected it is to modern cultural movements (hyper pop is deeply tied to LGBTQ+ culture), so many of these kids don’t care about things like if the master redlines or there’s masking—if that’s what gets their energy across, they’ll want that in the mix.

author: BillyC
content: I just import some VCAs, FX returns, mix bus, and print track. All other routing is only done as needed, because routing decisions are really about processing. And those decisions are hard to make until I’ve heard the song and can see what stems I have to work from. I’ve just gotten too many sessions from people where there is so much bussing and subgrouping going on that by the time the vocal gets to the mix bus, it is passed through 3 instances off gullfoss and 4 different compressors and there is zero life in it. It quickly gets out of control. I actually find minimal bussing to be a quicker workflow because I don’t have to follow a whole series of subgroups to know the entire processing chain on a given audio source when I’m trying to make a tweak, nor will that tweak affect any other element that is sitting just fine. That’s just my brain though.

author: Jeremy Klein
content: what are the pros/cons of high passing a vocal (90hz ish) before a compressor? I've always done it without ever considering if there are any merits _not_ to do it.

author: Jeremy Klein
content: dope, thanks for that! i constantly want more low end thickness in my vocals without them being woofy, and started to wonder if that was causing them to be thinner than i wanted.

author: NoahNeedleman
content:
High passing the vocals right below the fundamental shouldn’t kill any low end thickness- if anything it’ll give you a little hump there. 

There are a lot of compressors that add low end resonance, some more musical than others. UAD 175-B and Fairchild do really well with that for my taste. 

Bottom without woof and top without sibilance are what make your vocals sound pro, and there’s no one way to skin that cat properly.

author: Jeremy Klein

author: ehutton21

author: Adam Thein
content: To expand on this idea, I’ve also had good luck with making a sine wave with a pitch envelope similar to like an 808 or more of an edm kick and start with it tuned to the kick drum fundamental and pitch downward - I haven’t had a ton of luck personally with using the tuning of the key of the song cause it becomes pretty boomy.  Also I’ve had good luck taking that pitch envelope sine or triangle and throwing a volume shaper (I use Devious Machines Duck) and sidechain that to the kick in mic, play with the shape so that it doesn’t interact with the transient, or print the whole thing to audio and play around with the timing so your sub is slightly behind the beat so your kick transient can still remain clear and your sub can bloom behind the transient.  Depends a lot on what your bass instruments are doing also but something to try!

author: ehutton21
content: I did something real close to this! I used a synthesizer to create a sub harmonic at the low end range (30hz and below was lacking in the kick) and i layered it in with the kick at a barely audible level. Then I carved the OG kick with my tuner up so I can see how my moves were affecting things, added some sub harmonics to the og kick with waves lo air & the smallest amount of RBass possible, and it sits real well now

author: ehutton21
content: Especially for that “big kick” effect that got popular with hip hop and dance, I have a lot of luck tuning the kick to sit in a complimentary harmonic position rather than forcing it down to the root fundamental. If I do that though, the bass has zero room to be out of key or unusual (never usually is but sometimes I’ve had weirdly tuned synth basses sent to me, dunno how but 🤷‍♂️ )

author: Slow Hand
content:
I've been playing around with the new *Stabilizer* module in *Ozone 10* (which is similar to Gullfoss), and I dig it. It's not bad. I've been using it on my 2-buss for my last two mixes.

*However,* you have to be careful with it. If you solo an instrument/group/etc, it will adapt its curve to *those* instruments, meaning it's now optimizing it's EQ for the subgroup, which can misrepresent the moves that you need to be making.

I'm also realizing that printing stems is going to be problematic with that on a stereo buss because the *Stabilizer* is going to adapt it's curve to each solo'd channel (facepalm).

On second-thought, this might be best reserved as a mastering tool only, or else only lean on it *very* lightly and print your stems with it off.

author: Tyler Graham
content: Question: What are specific mix decisions that will alter the perceived timing of a vocal? My PDC is fine - i think - on pro tools but after finishing a mix it seems the pocket has been altered (vocals slightly late). Maybe the rough was just muddier and the pocket was kind of obscured?

author: samvalentine
content: My first guess would be the mix has a different verb size (maybe predelay) or delay speed than the rough. Even subtle changes to time-based effects can alter the pocket of a vocal. Compression attack time could also be a culprit. Definitely not unusual to impart subtle pocket changes if you’re doing some heavily lifting in the mix. Don’t be afraid to nudge the whole vocal a bit to solidify the pocket.
