author: Zach Hughes
content:
Catching up on the thread from yesterday which is a really fascinating topic to me. I found it interesting that the conversation began with discussions around giving the market what it wants, status, feelings of entitlement but then ended in the territory of everything is subjective and if it sounds good it's good.

Expanding on the entitlement piece: I see two camps. Those who have had success in the industry, but the headwinds are changing and they  fear going the way of the dodo. Sentiment being 'i ought to be able to keep doing what I was doing that worked for me before'. And then folks who want to make the best art they can by following their own unique taste / vision, charting a new path, who are disappointed when the market doesn't reward them enough for it.

How do we reconcile giving the market what it wants with everything is subjective / if it sounds good it is good?

author: Deleted User
content:
I’m ruling out the performance since you said it is smooth- but great bass guitar performance often don’t need much clip gain because good players know how to adjust their touch to the acoustic properties of the instrument.

Sometimes it’s arrangement, when instruments are playing notes that aren’t really meaningful to the arrangement then it won’t cut through the mix. Or if the other instruments are doing things that aren’t meaningful to the arrangement, it can get contribute to bass notes getting lost as well. 
Try muting other stuff one at a time until you can hear the bass well, and evaluate why the bass isn’t cutting through. 

Sometimes, you just gotta zoom out and mute the bass and mix the song without the bass and put it in. Before you do this, save as and solo vocals (if there is any) bass and drums (sometimes one other most important/prominent element in the arrangement on top of that) and make that work first. You can get it to a point of making the mix work this way if there is one element that just doesn’t sit well in the mix.

author: popthetrunk
content: The brown vs black on ssl are from actual hardware design changes. Brown is earlier with less than 18db +/- range and less aggressive q range, hence the “smooth”, also had less headroom in the low band. Also the filters were always in circuit even if rolled all the way down. Black was more surgical and introduced after there were a couple known mix engineers at that point asking for mods that had made it into subsequent versions, had more headroom so you could push the low band.

author: Zack Hames
content:
Varies client to client, relationship to relationship. 

Reasons not to overexplain: Let them have their experience, don't put anything in their head. They may just be stoked and then you get the mix approved. 

Working in the Ad-World: They *dont give a FUCK* about your explanation. They just want to see it and if it's good they'll go "awesome. thanks bye we got other shit to do". 

Reasons to explain: 
These people have a hard time letting themselves just experience the song, or if you have a SLEW of revisions, sometimes it's nice to address each one individually. 

Example:

"Turned up the bass, fixed that transition in the prechorus, made the guitars less harsh and more spacy in the verses. let me know how that feels".

Whatever....I think there's strategic and emotional reasons to do both.

author: Zack Hames
content: If someone asks every time you send a mix "so what did you do? What's different?" feel free to explain. most artists don't give a shit if you say "I boosted 2k on the lead vocal, adjusted the pre-delay on the reverb, and side-chained the bass to the kick drum"

I feel like part of my issue is not giving myself enough headroom for the louder sections of the song to develop into, but I’m thinking that my problem is how I’m perceiving the role of the 2bus limiter and how often I “want” it to be triggered, and how much dynamic range needs to be controlled at the bus level beforehand… I aspire to be a wizard someday 😅

author: Adam Thein
content: One of my favorite things to do instead of a riser is to print down a longer verb like a 4-5 second plate on a throw, print it into audio, and then stack Utility plugs in ableton and just unnatural boost the tail of that verb into a swell.  Slightly different effect than a reverse reverb but can make some interesting transitions that way or emphasize a certain lyric subtly.

author: Adam Thein
content: Also the insane-o mode on this that I've done before is checking the phase on every note between all bass layers against every kick, but obviously doesn't help you with bass layers on sustained notes that are modulating - I'd go steeper than 12db/octave if you have to and deal with the consequences of phase shift by making the crossover point somewhere where you don't need a ton of bass (snare fundamental range?)

author: spectrummasters
content: Along with others suggestions , I would advise some easy quick  tools to help you diagnose  . Izotope insight has a very good spectrograph that clearly reveals what’s happening down at 20-30 hz and how much energy is there . We ve also discussed izotope tonal balance here as well , but it’s really a very handy diagnostic when used to investigate where your low end energy is against a referenced track you like . Izotope Match eq is another tool that again allows you to compare and contrast what’s happening in your low end . I’ve also found the Shawn Everett trick mentioned here , useful for investigating low end (put a brick wall low pass filter on your mixbus and sweep it down to the 20-30hz with your subs on and see what that actually sounds and feels like . The other thing I find helpful is my gain staging and buses are set up so that I know how much gr and level should be arriving at each bus , so you soon know if you’re too hot just by looking at the comp / limiter . The last thing I’d say is know your speakers . I apply all this to myself because translation is my main point of focus right now . I forget where I heard it said , but I heard it said that the listener hears the inverse of what we the mixers hear .

author: Maxim

author: Deleted User
content:
The bigness of synth and samples probably is at the consistency of it, but I always felt like acoustic instruments takes less work to sound big and immersive because they already are. Acoustic instruments may take compression, editing and some aggressive band limiting and EQ moves to make it work in the mix, but those moves tend not to work for synths in my experience. So other things need to be done like parameter automation and layering

Bass guitar is probably not gonna have as consistent in your face subs like 808s, but the life of it always felt more massive than 808 to me. 

Soft synths sound huge on their own because they have very consistent presence but when you turn the faders down for balance, it gets smaller again. So  as many mentioned it takes making it smaller to make it bigger again. I guess this also applies to distorted guitars

author: andrewrs
content:
Some questions about mix bus limiting and loudness/lufs:

Firstly, how to deal with odd hits where the limiter jumps an extra 4-6db of limiting. I’ve tried limiting my drum bus, but it takes extreme limiting on the drum bus to have an effect on mix bus limiter (and I don’t totally understand why). I guess I could try limiting drums/bass together, as maybe it’s a phase issue with kick and bass adding together (talking live drums here, not programmed)… but any thoughts here are appreciated. 

Secondly, what range of limiting (aka -2 to -6db) are you guys doing on mix bus to have your overall mix at around-9lufs? I have been trying to only hit -2db of limiting on peaks for most of my mix, but have a really tough time accomplishing this and loudness. I love heavy/punchy low end, so maybe that’s why.. 

I guess I have this idea/goal in mind that I should be able to make -9lufs mixes that are punchy with a lot of low end, while only hitting 2db of limiting, but it seems impossible. Is it?

author: stefanmacc
content:
There are others here that can probably answer this better. But IMO you don’t want to rely on the limiter as a way to achieve loudness or excitement in a mix because you’ll likely end up with a crushed muddy mess… The limiter is not very good at those jobs.

Also LUFS is perceived loudness meaning EQ plays a huge role in that.. Distortion / Saturation plays a big role..  

So limiting should be one slice of the pie when it comes to achieving level… the rest should be done within the mix with the correct EQ moves . Correct distortion and some compression (not too much)

author: NoahNeedleman
content:
I do a LOT of these. Couple things that help me:
Dynamics are your friend in arrangements like this. No need to use compression to bring things forward cause there’s only two things right?
I end up spending most of your time cleaning things like mouth noises, detailing esses, string squeal, etc. 
FX tend to be obvious in these contexts so the work is to be subtle.
Also cian & Jack are spot on IMO.

author: stefanmacc
content: You should watch Shawn Everett on mix with the masters. He starts a mix with 5 tape emulators on the bus and his mix is -8 lufs right away. Zero limiting . Each tape plug is gently lowering the dynamic range in a subtle way

author: Zack Hames
content: When you record multiple kick mics (kick in, out, sub kick, etc) do you compress them all separately or do you bus them all and compress the bus?

author: esquinalee
content:
I like to put an ssl-g comp style channel strip plug with eq, gating, and compression specific to the kick in and kick out, very subtly use standard clip to taste on each of the two (or not/or later on the bus) and bus those both to a kick bus where I’ll do some additive eq and a tiny bit of compression and then bounce it down to just one kick track once the balance between them is set and the character of the sound is together.
I find it’s nice to have the kicks all one aux and it’s easier to control the sound as one without dealing with different mic sources and sometimes it’s nice to not even route the kick bus to the drum bus, depending on the song and desired effect.

author: joaomartins
content: 100%!! we’re not here to serve our egos but to serve the song and sometimes what we think is better for the track it’s not what it’s asking for. If the track doesn’t need a certain “signature” I’m not gonna do it just to justify having my name as credit for mixing. One might like big drums, bright vocals, big low end, etc. but if the song doesn’t ask for it why do it just for the sake of it? I find I connect wayyy better emotionally to mixes that are serving the song and the characteristics of it rather than the perfectly balanced and polished mix in theory. Sometimes we have to do a lot of heavy lifting and that’s cool too, but if the record just asks for the last 5% so be it. If I got a track from Jack Antonoff or Blake Slatkin I imagine they’re not looking to have their shit reimagined

author: spectrummasters
content:
....aw, found the old explanation of why....re: vu meter before the limiter and lufs after. 
This of course will be elementary stuff for everyone in here ...but might as well leave it here for a reminder/refresher. 

1. The VU meter to highlight how the mix is behaving pre-limiter :
VU (Volume Unit) Meters essentially display an average of what we hear, rather than the very fast peaks that we don’t. they will show you the energy in the low end, and if there is radical movement, then you probably have an issue with frequencies that you aren’t hearing.VU meters should “dance” smoothly and in a gentle manner, usually in time with the music, rather than in big jumps and erratic, out of time movement.  This erratic movement implies that there are drastic level changes, which will be hard to control in mastering and need addressing in the mix.  

2. The LUFS meter post limiter to set your loudness levels

Personally, i dont use this MO ...i like izotope tonal balance to monitor the mix but....just wanted to share what i rememmbered about people using vu ITB

author: stefandurandt
content: I use an Analog VU meter on the output of my monitor controller built by the inhouse tech who also worked at Neve (he designed and built the 8816 summing box) - he recommended the Sifam ones because their ballistics are really good - which I think is the main argument for analog vs digital. I started using them itb after Leon Zervos who masters at 301 where I work but used to work at Sterling (where he mastered classics like mambo nr 5, the macarena, Avril Lavigne, Maroon 5 etc.) recommended them & spoke about the same “dancing” thing that @spectrummasters spoke about. After that I also got another 2  lessons by 301 mastering engineers (one who’s won like 19 aria - australian grammies & been nominated for like 90) - once where I gave a floortom too much bottom end $ & that really triggered a mastering compressor limiting him in some way & he showed me how the left side jumped on the vu - I didn’t hear it at all in the mixing room but could hear it clearly in the mastering room. The other engineer showed me the same thing this time with a powerful lead vocal. This was kinda back when the loudness wars were still a bit more relevant & when I delivered quiter mixes & left them more space to do their thing & these energy bursts limited the final loudness potential. Then I saw that same Jacquire King thing & together all this made me think of how useful the VU is if you’re working in less than ideal bass monitoring environment - it really shows the bass energy in a pretty unique way. I like listening to references (check the bass VU on for instance Jon Castelli’s Khalid Talk vs Sza Low - one very kick focused & one super sub focussed - both a fuckton of low end vs Serban Blinding Lights try -7 as the reference - BL hovers around 0 & is louder lufs wise & then try Fleetwood Mac Dreams (I think the 2012 remaster) - softer, nice transients, beautiful bass - being driven by Kick,snare & bass) - all of those “dance” with the groove.

author: stefandurandt
content: I normally start a mix by listening to the references & watching the VU meter if it has a whole heap of sub it’s be more pinned, lots of kick - more jumpy, less bass overall but louder more even. Good mixes will generally bounce with the groove of the track. I don’t base everything I do on this it’s just a check every now & then once I start mixing same as the clarity - it & the clarity together give me all the info I need - but very different. One “energy” or how it’ll make you dance 🙂 & the other frequency, loudness over time, phase etc.

author: JustinLeu
content:
I think this is important to realize WHY this is working. The polarity flip is making the drums (as a whole) sum the waveforms in a more pleasing and additive way. 
The way I theorize this is happening is because while all of the drum mics relative phase relationships remain the same, the frequencies that the drums produces slightly vary during a performance. These are NOT one shot samples going through the microphones. The 4 on the floor makes it much more complex because BOTH the snare and the kick are producing different tones (with variances) at the same time…The frequencies that are additive (in-phase) are relative to all of the drum mics positioning/distance from the source, BUT different frequencies will add/subtract in magnitude…that is what we are quickly checking with polarity. If you change the tuning on a snare drum for instance, it can start to become less “in phase” with the overheads because the fundamental frequency has changed and may not be complimentary between the OH/SN mics anymore at the same distance.

author: Eric Martin
content: To my ears, I hear things that I’m not in love with in this processing, so I can’t be more subjective on the matter. I can say that the polarity of a snare mic pushes away from the mic first and then rebounds

author: Will Melones
content: I’ve had this with the relationship between kick in and overheads. It *looks* like the waveforms are opposing each other. And it makes sense—air pressure is pushed toward the kick in mic while it’s moving away from the overheads. But flipping the polarity sucks out all the low end. Sometimes that big bump at the beginning of the waveform may not be what you’re hearing as the fundamental. Just gotta trust your ears over your eyes. And air *isn’t* just moving away from the overheads, because the lowest frequencies are exploding outward in every direction, up and back into those mics as well.

author: Ross Fortune
content:
[Apologies for long message, I’m thinking out loud but also detail is probably useful] Gearing up to mix a live album with a heap of songs (tbc but potentially 23 in one show).

The last time I did something like this, it was low channel count -   a couple of acoustics, one or two vocals, maybe a keyboard per song. I mixed the whole thing in one Pro Tools session, with a separate set of channels for each song which I’d then make inactive and move onto the next song. When printing the continuous mix at the end, I’d make active two songs at a time for any overlap, and constructed the long printed mix like that.

In this case though, there are multimiced drums, bass, electric guitars, keyboards, vocals. The recordings are good (from the stereo board mixes I’ve heard) and the scale is such that I want to have the fidelity I’d approach a studio record with, and the room to shape an identity for each song (while still sounding like they all happened on the same stage on the same night) so I’m thinking to use my usual elaborate drum mix routing with parallels etc, all the bells and whistles.

This complexity would put me off mixing 23 songs in one session, but I’m thinking of the inevitable crunch at the end of the project and the potential frustration of jumping between sessions.

Am I thinking too deeply about this? Should I just get a drum sound and leave it there for 23 tracks, with a few rides here and there?

Not much experience with this stuff so any thoughts would be very welcome please!

author: Will Melones
content:
I have nowhere near the experience you do, but I’d approach this in one session. So when you get to song 16 and discover that perfect kick sound, or get a note from the artist that the bass could come up 2dB for the whole show, you’re not opening 23 sessions to revise.

But my approach would also be one set of tracks from beginning to end, just like you’re mixing it live, and prepare to automate. What made you choose a separate set of channels for each song?

author: lystell
content:
On the topic of EQ
I'm doing some projects now that are live drums driven so to speak. I'm trying to up my game both when it comes to recording and mixing. 
My instinct when it comes to EQ is to subtract. In a way, it feels logical to me. Let's say I don't like the sound on a snare around 400hZ. Then my brain goes - let's remove that. 
I've been digging deeper lately into the API style of EQ and it occurred to me that when going through the preset list -  most of the presets were doing additive stuff. I find this very interesting and when it comes to "surgical sounddesign",  a new workflow for me. Like - I don't like the low mid on this snare. Let's boost the top instead. 
It feels somewhat backward but I can see some good things coming of it. 
How's your workflow?

author: NoahNeedleman
content:
A producer buddy of mine asked me yesterday how often I listen in mono while mixing. I said “When I find myself using too many stereo imagers to make things fit, sometimes I’ll check to see what kind of fuckery I’m causing. But honestly who listens in mono anymore?”

He reminded me a lot of small Bluetooth speakers are in mono, so I decided this morning to take a fresh look at a tune I’m producing/mixing, starting in mono. 

The leveling choices totally broke down when I switched to stereo, but I think the mix is much better and it happened faster cause I was forced to look at the eq in relation to the center elements, so even when I spread them back out there was more room for the vocal kik snare bass to speak. 

Y’all ever start a mix in mono? Or work with mono as a tool for extended periods?

author: Adam Thein
content:
I don't do a ton of referencing while mixing anymore but it definitely was and still is a key for learning new things.

I mostly work with young indie artists and producers who are still finding their sound and it's very common for me to get notes like "can we make the guitar solo sound like XYZ song from ABC artist," and usually after a little bit of frustration I work my way through to a new trick up my sleeve by dissecting a sound and trying to recreate it.

I think the major pitfall to avoid though for mixers and producers just at the beginning is understanding that you can't squeeze blood from a stone - not getting discouraged or into the pit of despair if your bedroom produced track with amp sims and samples isn't standing up against the big budget Studio A level records.  But that doesn't mean you can't start learning what a great bass tone is in a mix and why it's working by listening to those intently.

author: Josh Bowman
content: If it’s a modern/pop/“competitive” (ugh I hate that word but you know what I mean) genre how I deal with this in recent years is to make sure the arrangement is doing the heavy lifting instead of actual volume to get the feeling of dynamics, instead of making the song too dynamic (ie quiet parts too quiet). I always do a quiet listen or a headphone city walk to see if I loose important elements in the quiet bits to make sure I don’t overshoot the dynamics. Also don’t get stuck in a loop of just one section for too long. Also sometimes I start the intro a little louder and slowly let the volume settle to where I actually want it in the verse if I want it to actually be a bit more dynamic… just a subtle bump of the intro guitar/piano etc then let it settle under the vocal can help it appear loud enough in a playlist off the top and still let you have some contrast from verse to chorus. I know I said two conflicting things- depends on the arrangement

author: RÜSSO
content: am interested in knowing how, when, and why i should mid/side processing, specifically for EQing, but knowing more about it, generally speaking, would be helpful! i read somewhere suggesting that raising the low mid gain and reducing the stereo lows would put the, say, bass in front of the mix. it’s true, but i don’t understand why or how it could be helpful.

author: NoahNeedleman
content:
So think of mid vs side in terms of panning left right & center, and think of EQ as volume. 

If you’ve got a lot of low end information on the sides, and say it’s fighting with a mono bass track that’s supposed to be holding down the majority of the low end, you can eq the lows out of those panned tracks, or you can blanket turn all the lows down on the sides with a m/s eq on a buss, so that the L and R info is quieter. It’s basically a group volume ride for frequencies instead of tracks. You can also do this on individual stereo tracks if just panning isn’t granular enough. 

The why & when is mostly about taste. I tend to mix into a proQ3 setting that has the sides hi passed around 100 for the same reason I have a pultec boosting highs & lows on the master- it just ends up doing a lot of work for me.

It can become problematic if I’ve got big toms in a song and, after I’ve got a mix starting to cook I’ll toggle it on & off to see if I’m doing more harm than good. For the kind of music I mostly do, it works more often than not, but the one song I sent to Cian for mixing he basically blasted me for doing that. (In his own kind and gentle way.)

But m/s eq isn’t just for the master buss. You can think about it for any stereo track. Sometimes, I have an acoustic that’s carrying the whole song, but the fundamentals are fighting with the vocal, so I’ll turn the mid down at that frequency (or side chain that to the vocal if it feels anemic when the vocal is out.) that leaves the sides as big as you like cause it’s not fighting with my mono vocal.

author: Joshua Riley

author: JakeTB
content: Not disagreeing here, but one additional piece to consider: Gullfoss can “undo” certain mix moves, making it tough to put things “out of balance”. For instance, if one needs to turn up a hihat, Gullfoss is likely to reactively attenuate 8-16k. It’s less of an issue at subtle settings, but dancing around the limitations while trying to retain flow state is a real drawback.

How are y’all organizing and routing your effects and why?

author: river
content:
As I like to mix loud, I take inspiration from a method I found called "clip to zero" when it comes to returns/buses/groups (I'll name them buses.)
And also Skrillex and his crazy groups. He showed his screen for a music video a while ago so it's prolly changed but still gave me inspiration.

It'll look something like
Drum bus + drum room bus, grouped together = drum sum bus.
Synth bus  + synth FX bus = synth sum bus
Vocal bus + vocal fx bus = vocal sum.

If it calls for it and I'm feeling spicy, have another group which contains just my bass elements as their own sum group.

Depending on the track, and how important I think any single element is over the other, I might do something like further group/bus together my drums and synths. Leaving me with 2 buses to balance against each other.

author: f.ern___
content:
Here's what I did. 
Made session with a bunch of group channels. Namely these:
Kicks, Snares/Claps, High End Perc, All Drums, All Bass, All Music, LDV and BGV. 

Kicks, snares, percs was routed to the ALL Drums as well. Any transition FX was also routed to All Drums. 

On each of these groups I had an izotope insight 2 channel. 

I then loaded a bunch of stems and routed them to the proper channels. Some came with only a drum bus channel so I could check the kick and snare on their own. 

I set the levels so all mixes peaked at -4dB. 

Here's the songs I looked at:
100 Gecs - Stupid Horse
Ariana Grande - No Tears left to cry
The Weeknd - Blinding Lights
Charli XCX - Forever
Ava Max - Turn Off The Lights
Dua Lipa - New Rules
The 1975 - Give yourself a try

Here's what I found

author: f.ern___
content:
The All Drums group was pretty much consistent over all these tracks hitting peaks at -7dB and and RMS at -15 or 16. Ava max had peaks at -5. 

Most kicks had peaks at -9.5 to -10dB. Ava Maxs which is was more dance heavy peaked at -6. RMS on all stayed within the -14 to -16 range. 

Snares peaks was about 1dB louder than the kick on all tracks and ranged between 8.5 and 11. Rms sat between -22 and -24 on all. Ava Max is exluded cause there was a kick on the snare stem. 

High end percs had peaks around -20 to -25 and rms around -35-40. 

on the All BASS channel the peaks varied a bit more ranging between -8.5 and -12dB. Most sat between 8.5 and 10 though. For rms they were all around 15-16 apart from 1975 again hitting -18. 

The All Music Group all had an RMS of -18 to -20 but the peaks varied -6dB to -11dB

the LDV group (which sometimes also had the BGVs in the stem) varied more than I thought and had peaks between -7 and -14.5. Most sat around -10 to -12. Ava had the lowest ldv, possibly in favor for the stronger drums. On most tracks the RMS sat at -20.

BGV. The bgvs include to many different types of elements to draw any conclusion but they all had overall RMS between -21 and -25.

author: f.ern___
content: some I only have like "all drums, all bass, all music and all vocals" of.

author: f.ern___
content:
Some further insight:
The difference in RMS of the ALL DRUMS an ALL BASS per song is never more than 1dB. More oftan than not it's exactly the same.

author: Slow Hand
content:
I'm a big fan of Goodhertz *Tupe* for parallel distortion. While it's not going to be the right flavor for every situation they implement it well. It has an excellent *Emphasis* section that allows you to emphasize/de-emphasize frequencies going into and coming out of the distortion circuit. 

This means that you can get the entire source sound to hit the distortion circuit evenly. Akin to making it fit your sound like a glove and saturate very evenly, rather than having the bass blow out the distortion before your mids or high-end can be saturated. Then I blend to taste with the dry/wet fader in the plugin.

author: Rob Domos
content:
Seeing a few people tagging me asking for more deets. I’m on holiday with fam now so a little write up will need to suffice. 

Jack’s video covered a good chunk of what I’m doing. Attenuating a few frequency hotspots and clicks is more than half of it. Unlike Jack, I use mouth declick far more than spectral repair or declick. 

There’s other things I’m doing as well but they vary from song to song. I’ll manually smooth out plosives, mic stand bumps, clothing rustles etc. I’ve even gone through and reduced the aliasing in a processed vocal (which takes fucking forever to lasso tool). 

One thing I’ve never seen anyone mention before is fades in RX. It’s a little hard to explain so I’d have to make a video for this, but I do frequency dependent fading. If you think about it, almost all sounds decay with the high end decaying faster than the low end, so when I’m fading noise floor I do the same and the result is more natural and invisible.

author: Nomograph Mastering
content:
Great, we’ve all kind of known that. Back to FFT, which works in a LINEAR  way. If we run a 16 “band” FFT on a 48 kHz signal it will divide the audio spectrum (0 Hz to 24 kHz) into 16 evenly spaced bins or bands. Each bin is 1500 Hz wide. Think about that for a second. That means we have a a single bin that contains everything from 16500 to 18000 Hz, a very “narrow” slice as it pertains to musical interest. On the flip side we are left with only a single bin that represents everything from 0 Hz to 1500 Hz, a huge chunk of the music. If the whole point was to slice up this signal so we could do something interesting to it then that is often not the resolution we hoped for. 

I see the hands going up!! “Let’s just increase the number of bands to get more frequency resolution”. And herein lies one of the confounding things about FFT. We are caught in a frequency domain/time domain tradeoff. The finer the bands or slices the more things blur in the time domain when we reconstitute via the iFFT (of the bands we have processed any or all bands). If no processing then you can run any length FFT and then the iFFT and perfectly reconstruct the original signal. (This is what you’ll often see 16 to 48k FFT on signal meters).

So some practical examples to help you guys get a handle on this. Open a file in RX and get the spectral repair module in attenuate mode set to a strength of 1. Set bands to the lowest possible (128?), figure out how wide your bins are. Now try to do a detailed edit in the low end, you’ll notice that you don’t have much “resolution”, but up high say above 10k it’s razor sharp. Now bump up your bands to the max 4096. Do the same LF edit and you’ll suddenly have nice narrow frequency slices but you’ll see things getting very blurry in the time domain, tight kicks become smeary whooshes

author: Deleted User
content:
Question for those who use Low bus to compress kick and bass together:

what kind of gain reduction are you doing? and how much?

I did a parallel on UAD 33609 and it felt pretty nice, the kick and the bass was feeling a little too over taking and parallel compression allowed me to tuck it back a little without losing their presence. 

So I was curious if anyone is doing something different on the low bus and why

author: spectrummasters
content: ...im aiming for the dynamic range between the moments where the kick and bass hit seperately...to when they hit together....to be my low end dynamic overall (if that makes sense)....so i dont want to flatten that range there....and instead prefer to compress the kick and bass seprately on their own buses . Im using parrallels of my kick and bass to get my loudness and harmonics, pre Low End Bus . If id want more control id consider a hz-dependent side chain on the bass from the kick, but dont like how that f's with the attack of the bass. Trying to do less processing at all stages......and get there with better balancing ..... So...a tiny bit of  comp on the kick and bass buses (0.5 db slow attack, fast release...usually neutron comp) and only an eq and standard clip on the kick bass bus to only catch random peaks and not jam the final  limiter . i like a littler expansion also , playing around with the pro G expnasion mode is fun

author: BoozleBAM
content: I'm glad that you mention the 0.5 dB here. See, here's my thing with compression: I do like to absolutely smash my bass with compression because I like the sound of a really pinned down bass, and vocals is a given, but other than those two sources, I really don't compress. What I've found is that once I compress one thing,  I find myself going,  "Oh, this thing needs to be brought up, and then this thing and then this thing..." and then I end up in a "loudness war" with myself. I know tons of people who compress the day lights out of everything, and more power to them. Sometimes I wish I could make it work for me... I also find compression somehow takes away from the impact of things as well, in a way.

author: Nick Stetina

It’s easy to listen in band solo, and the corrective EQ you have up becomes Thor’s hammer and everything sounds like a nail that need.smash.now. Especially in that ‘Bass’ band…it can be illuminating in some pop stuff, like “oh, they really cleaned up the low end on the sides, there’s this certain V-shape going to the mix in an M/S sense” but I’ve totally neutered what was cool about drum room mics in a mix when trying this approach on a more natural sounding punk/rock tune. So I guess as with anything with great power comes great responsibility, haha

author: BoozleBAM
content: Agreed! Hpf and lpf seem to be all the rage and I'm not exactly sure why. I think it might be because it looks prettier. Lol. author: Marty Byrde
content:
I have two mixing questions for anyone that can help me answer…

1. Whenever I high pass my vocals (especially past 100hz) I start to hear some weird phase type of effect… idk what it is but I hate it. But when I don’t high pass my vocals past 100-120 hz, my vocals sounds too boomy, like the low end of my vocals is too overpowering the mix when I play it in my car…. Is there a way I can go around this?

2. Other than delay throws, When people put a constant delay on vocals it seems like they want the delay to be felt not heard….. if this is the case, how does the delay not being heard help the mix….? Or am I just thinking too deep into it?
Thanks in advance

author: cy (sigh)
content:
phase shift with high pass filters are pretty common but rarely sounds too intense unless the center freq is in the middle of of a lot of info, I'm sure someone more technically savvy can run point on this better. 

but no2 is pretty simple. we both hear and feel music. those delays often add a feeling of depth or can also be used to enhance /adjust grooves in a way that's not invasive, Ina way that make a difference to the feeling of the music but may not be obvious when only focusing on how it sounds

author: Edward Rivera
content: It’s not intuitive but it’s common to use HPF in conjunction with low shelf cuts, low bell cuts, or a combination of all 3. That’s the beauty of a parametric eq. Very flexible. I myself don’t like hi passing beyond 40 or 70 (old superstitions) but then you can notch out the offending frequency once that’s set

author: montrose recording
content: what eq are you using?  you could try a fairly LF HP of say 60hz and then a tilt eq or low shelf.  i personally dont experience this phase effect you're speaking of but hey who knows.   through plugins or outboard i've been high passing things since i first started tracking and have never experienced a phase-y affect, especially when it's just one mic on the source.  so perhaps there is something else going on like josh mentioned

author: Rob Domos
content:
1) I know exactly what you’re talking about. For me, a couple things have helped 

- try shelving the lows rather than use a HPF. I’ll even cascade a couple of shelves sometimes if I have to go crazy, or shelve 150 and HP 50. You can get similar amounts of attenuation and the shape of the phase rotation feels a little less fake.

- how much of this are you doing in solo? Often the phase fuckery bothers me in solo and doesn’t as soon as the 808 is bumping. 

- sometimes I just let the lowend be loose and say “fuck it. My mix, my aesthetic choice”. Seems like not many agree but I like lowend in my vocal.

It does a cool “something” on bass guitar in a metal/rock context for me that in particular helps on smaller speakers, but also helps to fill out space where some notes are naturally stronger than others. It helps me avoid a lot of tedious automation and multiband babysitting in addition to providing somewhat of a rock solid “concrete slab” consistent low end. I always loved what Rbass did but the effect vanishes a little when the progression of the song moves to a different note - automating the frequency in question (super low, where A = 55hz) solves that problem for me but is a chore to do.

author: peterlabberton
content:
I’m not gonna dig through search or anything like that, but @M3MIYAGI, here’s what I’ve been doing for the last several years more or less (still refining/tweaking but basically the same). A lot of it stolen from @cian riordan and from this Discord, lots of wisdom from @Nomograph Mastering included.

Minimal buss compression (1-3db on loudest sections of a mix), usually some kind of tape saturation (typically Slate Virtual Tape Machine), and Pro L2. The limiter is only grabbing 3-4 dB for the most part with the odd drum hit or whatever hitting more. Rarely I’ll add in other processing to push things harder for a specific mix, but 95% of the time that’s it. Then it’s sub busses or processing on individual tracks to get the level and compression/limiting needed to get things slamming. Then for mastering I pull the gain on Pro L2 down 6 dB, print and call it a day.

author: Jonathan Jetter
content:
If loudness is a goal, then it's usually good to navigate that in the mix instead of waiting until mastering.

Also think it's often good to split the load across tracks vs. subgroups vs. the 2-mix, and to split the load between compression, saturation, limiting, clipping on various elements/groups/master.

Figuring out all of the above is easier with a limiter at the end.

author: joshbonanno
content: yeah, i typically try and avoid as much processing that will corner in to things like that as possible...even "turn the 808" notes up aside, the chances a producer is going to want to drop me a new file entirely is always there (sadly) and if dropping a new file in means the mix falls apart, thats a bad day for me also...so things like multiband...compression etc...i avoid doing any of that on busses or mixbus at all, and if i do its GENTLE. also, like @hyanrarvey typically it really is as simple as just turning it up and not thinking about it...everything affects everything.. and a louder 808 is going to make the vocal feel quieter, the mix feel a bit more compressed maybe etc...that is simply the nature of the note...sometimes i will even explain that to the artist if they come back and go "why does the vocal sound quiet now?"... "well, we turned up the 808 and the low end etc etc..." educate.

author: yaldaram
content: TLDR: The document discusses the claims of sound quality and superiority between different audio software. It concludes that no evidence supports these claims, and any perceived differences in sound are due to variations in software algorithms, particularly in how they handle signal levels and pan groups. These differences do not indicate one software's superiority over another but rather reflect different mixes with varying balances. The document also highlights that any discrepancies caused by third-party plugin incompatibilities should not be mistaken for differences in sound quality. The concept of "better sound" is subjective and not quantifiable.

author: EliHeathMusic
content: I played bass and keys on a week-long session Phil was producing last year out of his studio in Brooklyn. As someone who is often producing and mixing as well as playing instruments, it was extremely liberating to have another person (him) responsible for listening and making judgments about the takes. A lot of his recording process involves having bands tracking together live and I think it is hard to objectively judge the energy of a full band take if you were one of the musicians who just played on it (it can be easy to focus on your instrument, part execution over feel, etc). His process speeds up the session and allows the performers to create more freely with out having to worry about judging quality at the same time  but it does require a lot of trust in him as the producer. And he is doing a very specific type of music and recording.

author: masteredbyjack
content:
I can't speak to the mixing aspect of it (I only master), but a few points I've found helpful:

I use notion, but any type of board thing would be fine -- colums for "confirmed/files here", "sent", "revisions needed", "alts needed" (after approval usually), etc etc have helped. Trello or Notion allows you to keep any notes in the actual card itself, which may be helpful with management or more people involved. I have a separate Notion board for potential projects until files are in, then they go in the "actual" project tracker.

For the multiple messaging fronts...I use texts.com. All messaging apps in one place (email included, though you can't reply there) in an iMessage like format. I know @Nomograph Mastering has concerns about anything like that in regards to security, but I've looked into it and it seems very secure for where I'm at (anything sensitive I am password protecting files, etc as well).

As far as revisions, I'm sure most of us try to keep it as timely as possible. Normally I try to do it ASAP, same day or next day latest. And as you know, when you are busy revisions are a very real thing to consider, especially if your number of projects is high. I do revisions very fast -- take the note, implement it, send. For instance just yesterday was sailing along...BOOM. Revision from something two months ago. If you're working on hundred+ projects a month that's just the norm, even if 90 percent get approved first pass. Gotta be able to roll on that very fast, people really appreciate it (I know you know this, saying for others here too). Which requires good tracking, session management, etc etc.

The real trick is handing the very difficult revision processes where people go down rabbit holes, doing whatever is required for the result there but not letting it destroy the schedule. It can be tough.

All that said, I definitely have pain points I'm working on (being slow invoicing as one, sometimes there just aren't enough hours in the day)

author: Josh Bowman
content:
Oooff feel your pain that’s rough. This happens to me from time to time, not always that extreme tho.

Generally my first move is to listen while bypassing each thing and trying to identify what it’s making better and what gets worse, then if I decide to try and keep some of them I’ll attempt to move some of those plugs off the main mix buss and back onto a subgroup or instrumental buss. But no matter what it ends up with me looping sections and rebuilding the mix to match the rough vibe before I get into the actual creative fun part of the mix.

I have one producer i work with often who mixes into a comp on his all vocal buss and it’s slow and hitting like 3-6 db compression. It totally bones me while mixing so I usually end up rebalancing all the vocals section by section to match his mix before I “start mixing”. 

Sometimes I’ll just work into their buss shit and bypass the stuff/bands of each of plug that are only hurting and not helping. 

Real can of worms tbh. 

Last week I ran into the vocal buss issue- luckily it was a comp w side chain input so I did try out the sidechain, I pre fader sent all the tracks feeding it while copying automation to that send, then used a master fader to match the buss sc level to the original comps gain reduction  and it worked well in that situation and untied my hands while saving me from a whole vocal rebalance session. First time that approach ever actually worked though for me tbh. If its a comp that drums are driving into i find the sc input doesnt end up feeling the same usually.

author: cian riordan

And the SPL IRON i'm talking about is a plugin. Could you please elaborate more about "feed plugins for externsl sidechain to keep it closer to 1:1"? Thanks Adam!

author: Adam Thein
content:
All good it’s a little tricky at first and just really difficult to explain typed out for me.

Same concept as using a sidechain input from a kick drum to duck the 808 - an external sidechain allows us to give the compressor something to listen to and apply the compression from that source to another source.  When the kick is fed to a compressor on your 808 channel - the compressor “listens” to the kick and applies the compression curve from the kick onto the bass.

So in your case of printing stems with a mix bus compressor - you want the SPL Iron plugin to “listen” to the entire mix as it heard it before but then apply that compression to one track at a time.

We can do this in Ableton with some clever workarounds, which would be a lot more efficient to show you on a video call on the server if you are free later.  Essentially you need to print a version of your song at each point in your mix bus chain where there are dynamics plugins (just before the Slate plugin, just before the Iron Compressor but after all the other plugins) and then send that audio to those corresponding plugins’ external sidechain inputs and then you can use the “include return and master effects” and get the result you are looking for

author: shaunobi
content:
I use it and love it.

Near then end of a mix, I'll check it (in fine-grained mode, usually on the "bass heavy" curve). If I'm already sitting in the curve, I just leave it alone. If I'm a little out here and there (usually in the upper mids / highs for me) I'll put an eq (usually Weiss EQ MP or Pro Q3 - something that's not going to add "analog" saturation) right before it and make the changes it's suggesting, watching it to see if I got it close.

I think flip the EQ off and on to see if I like it more or less. Maybe half the time I DO like it more, though I often "back it off" a little, such that I'm like 50% or 70% of the way to what it's saying would be a "normal" mix.

The other ~half of the time I'm like "naw, don't like that" and disable the EQ.

author: Jack
content:
Going to assume you’re talking more Rumours than Aerosmith.

Drums: dbx 160, transient designer on close mics to thud things up, Fabfilter Saturns ‘dynamics’ knob works quite well to tighten things too, no slammin’ compression on room mics/overheads, sometimes hi-passing overheads into being ‘cymbal mics’ and giving the close mics their space 

Vocals: Dolby trick, not always super aggressively hi-passed, H3000/Microshift backing vocals

Guitars: acoustic 12 string layers, phasers/flangers, mid-forward drives, acoustic guitars often super hi-passed 

Bass: flatwound strings, picked 

Annoying answer: it’s mostly in the arrangement

author: Adam Thein
content: Pan law is additive in Logic and Ableton and subtractive in Pro Tools - so a fader set to 0db in Pro Tools with a center pan and a 3db pan law will peak at -3db whereas in Logic it will peak at 0db

Still too much. Clicked the wet solo off. Felt good. Drove the mix knob north again. Till too much. Landed where you see. Went to sink adjust the volume of the chamber underneath the bass. Go to -6db and lost some of the magic. I left the chamber louder than usual. And dragged down the overall bass volume to get the gain staging that felt balanced again in the mix

author: Mike Tierney
content: In that case, it's most likely just the timbre of the bassoon. Bassoon is kind of a funny instrument, it has a really wide note range but tends to have a slightly nasal-y tone because it naturally accentuates some of its harmonics. Some bass guitars kind of have this phenomenon, where even when they play an open E which should be 41Hz, you hear the harmonic more clearly at 82Hz

author: JustinLeu
content:
But honestly I feel like the LUFS level matching is a pretty nuanced topic. 

On one hand…
everyone only gets to work within 0db full scale, which is where “the loudness war” originated. The question becomes the trade off in loudness vs the mix suffering (which is a bit subjective)

On the other hand…
Most services default to roughly level matching songs to their target LUFS which is where the extremely misguided “loudness penalty” idea came from. BUT when services level matching different songs, sometimes you can get away with more dynamic range.

I typically do not worry at all about what number I’m hitting once a mix is feeling great. I may push it a bit louder to see what happens, and also check how it feels a bit more dynamic.

author: JustinLeu
content:
You could achieve the same numerical amount either way (no HPF or with HPF), the threshold would be different....but the same amount of compression is possible. 

What would be VERY different is how the compressed signal "feels" 

Think about what would happen if you keyed (side-chained) your mixbus compressor with the bass guitar vs if you keyed the compressor with just the snare drum. Given the same attack/release settings the entire mix would move differently.

author: Rob Domos
content: I think what I’m describing is way closer to your 400hz hpf than the way you’re seeing it

author: Rob Domos
content:
@Nomograph Mastering 

There’s so many layers to this conversation. 

One layer is: *are methods of reframing what you’re hearing inherently a crutch for poor monitoring?*

The 400hz high pass that you monitor through part time on every master would imply not. 

As someone with pretty good monitoring (80% of a Gerhard room and MUM 8s), I personally still find these kind of things very useful within a mixing context. 

I think you’re imagining a whackamole scenario of revolving bandpasses throughout the process and repeatedly throwing off the brain’s fr curve, when in reality it’s a once per mix check at the 85% mark that takes about 5 minutes total to see if anything that’s been overlooked jumps out when adjacent information isn’t distracting from it.

The way this helps me hone in on relationships between elements that I’ve been neglecting is pretty significant. I lean heavily “vocal > everything” when I mix, and nearly every time I do this bandpassing reframe I notice something I’d missed in the interplay between the rest of the elements and the whole project is upgraded as a result. 

I think it’s totally fair to warn against the pitfalls of such maneuvers in the same way that it’s fair to warn against abusing energy drinks, but when it’s just once a week before an intense workout, an energy drink is actually a big win with little to no downside.

author: Slow Hand
content:
Conceivably any vocoder would be sufficient because the harmonic richness depends on the carrier signal you feed into it, which could easily be any bright synth that you have on hand.

That said, even if you have a darker carrier signal you can usually “tilt” the vocoder bands towards more high end energy and less low end if you want it brighter.

Have you tried Izotope’s *Vocal Synth 2*? It has lots of vocoder-adjacent effects that will do similar things.

author: Gabriel Tyranny
content:
Oh interesting - For some reason my journey has led to me only reaching for the CLA76 on a parallel for the bass, but I should try it again in other contexts.

In case anyone would wanna try my approach to getting bass to play nice across more speakers / phones:

- I use the 20 ratio bluey to squash a bass parallel. Then I drive it through the free TSC 808 plugin for further emphasize the harmonics the bluey brings out. (EQ too)
- Then, I use Audreio on the master to play the mix through my phone instead of my monitors. Once on the phone, you can blend the parallel with the bass in a way where there’s little to no audible difference on a monitor, but the illusion of a bass can be heard through the harmonics playing on the phone.
- It’s a balancing act, but there’s almost always a nice sweet spot to be found where it doesn’t change the quality of the sound enough to be intrusively perceived on HD speakers, while giving life to the bass on lesser speakers.

This has helped my bass translate to more systems, and is the only time I find myself wanting to use the CLA76.

author: James Cronier
content: Track Control’s filter starts at 1Hz but it’s my understanding that the phase shift creeps in much higher, and that’s what makes the difference with these super low frequency filters.

author: James Cronier
content: Yeah totally. It’s possible YOUR all passes are undoing some of what the HPF are doing.

author: cian riordan
content: My annoyance here is that every track that gets an instance of Q4, gets an HPF.

author: James Cronier
content:
Yeah it’s silly. A lot of analog modeled plug-ins add very low HPFs. 

I don’t use a lot of HPF deliberately.

author: spectrummasters
content: I’ve tried so many times to really get confident with all pass filters (I have ssl x phase ) and I always end up back at square one after an hour lost a/b-ing . I’m driven to it because since I’ve moved into band based mixing , I find flipping phases 180 often improves either the mid or the low end between mics …(as expected ) but I dream of being able to get the best of both the mid and low end in these circumstances . That’s when I get lost in the all pass filter . I’ve never really found much guidance on how to get the best results …..I wonder do you have any sort of points to consider / suggestions to bear in mind when really trying to dial them in please Cian ? Tbh I’d love to hear anymore that you have to share about them in your experience ?

author: Brendan Trinkle
content:
Hi team, I've got a finger-style electric bass track in a mix that is a well played performance, but was inexpertly recorded on an instrument with some odd characteristics. The second harmonic is often louder than the fundamental, and any midrange available is just kind of clicky finger transient stuff. 

I've used RX to reduce the second harmonic to a more natural level (note by note), but the bass just still feels dark & doesn't cut on small speakers.

Re-recording the original player isn't an option, unfortunately. Are there any hive-mind suggestions to get more midrange character from a dark bass recording?

author: spookydrums
content: I feel like I get bass instruments with strong first and second harmonics, and also floor toms, a lot. I ususally dip a little in that frequency range and if it's a bass guitar what works for me to make it cut through more a lot of the time is Soundtoys Sie-Q with a healthy boost (think at around 3 o'clock) at 1.5 kHz. Oh, and SansAmp (the Audiopunks one is really good) can work wonders, either in-line or in parallell.

author: NoahNeedleman
content:
Yes. 2254 is go to for bass, 33609 for acoustics & vocal packages. They do a really great thickening & control without sounding real grabby. 

Very different flavor than a VCA opto or FET comp.

author: chrissorem
content: Your observation is correct. If you hit a drum, the pitch is changing if you hit a string on a guitar, bass  or any instrument, the pitch is fluctuating  What does this mean in the world of making records ? Basically nothing, it’s good to know, but not worth worrying about. transient shapers are envelope shapers. This is very important in creating music. It’s all fun to think about.

author: cameron
content: Ah ok, that makes sense! thanks 🙂 So what I’m still trying to understand is how to work with transients during mixing in a more practical way. As I said, a lot is about simple volume shaping, but that doesn’t always give me what I’m after. For example, how that octave layer trick translates to kicks. If I have a kick that I want to feel snappier on top, could I duplicate it and pitch it up an octave, or would that mess with the mid/low end? Or is it more about lifting the top with EQ to bring the transient forward? That always feels a bit strange when it’s pushed too hard, so I’m not sure if that’s the right approach either. Just curious how pro mix engineers handle it.

author: Matthew The Cooke🎄🎅🏻
content:
Have a bit of situation here that I’m not sure how to navigate on a song where I am producing and mixing

Currently on mix 51 of a song (which is not a problem in and of itself) and suddenly the artist says “I want everything under 150hz mono bc a famous EDM producer said so” 

Mind you the song is not EDM in any way shape or form also the feedback seems to be purely based on visual information he gets from some sort of stereo analyzer not something that actually bothers him when listening

Now the mix/production was not built in any way to be mono sub 150hz so there’s quite a bit more information there than on a typical EDM bc I tend not to surgically remove everything sub 100-150hz. So you get some of that in the keys, synths, guitars etc

I know it’s “flip the burger” etc but I was wondering if y’all had any advice on how to approach this

Don’t wanna argue with the artist ofc but just going and removing everything sub 150 seems like not a great idea so I figured might focus only on the bass instruments (which is really just an electric bass with a lot of low end) and try to make that as mono as possible

Any other advice?

author: Jonathan Jetter
content:
There's a small specific point I'd raise here about making sure both you + he are listening in ways where you can hear lows in stereo (i.e. *not* summing through a mono subwoofer).

There's a larger point about the overall process. To me it sounds like you're still producing the song. These kinds of things happen during mix sometimes, I fly in vocal fixes, etc. But usually in service of committing to a finished song.

author: Matthew The Cooke🎄🎅🏻
content: Yeah I‘m really happy with it and it‘s great which why so far I haven‘t had any problem with the notes… the mono bass was the one that pushed me over the edge tbh haha

author: Jonathan Jetter
content:
It all depends. I like the idea of the overheads being the whole kit but practically you need all of: a good drummer, good room, good tracking, good arrangement for that to work.

On a recent mix with a busy arrangement, not super tight playing, and questionable room acoustics, I turned the overheads into cymbal mics, HPF at 600, because otherwise it was just a mess with the doubled panned guitars.

author: hyanrarvey
content: if i am using the overheads to get the sound of the kit more than the close mics than i will be doing some nice boosts on the low end and the top end and some light compression

author: oaklandmatt
content:
I keep harping on this, but this is the direction things are heading for sure.

There are many mixers who still take something un mixed and then mix it.

There is also an increasing percentage of music (a lot of pop, essentially all of hip hop and r&b) where a mixer is taking mixed stems and making more subtle finishing changes (jon w billie, essentially all of Teezio and Bainz, etc).

The business has not caught up with this or found a great solution (*for the majority of situations where the whole team isn't already A list). 

If a song I'm asked to produce already has an A list mixer attached, I usually just give them my mix session and eat the fact that I've spent a lot longer on getting 95% of the mix done, and I just won't get a mix credit or royalty.

Otherwise I mix it myself or demand a co-mix (split fee and point). 

This is an increasing point of contention, but I don't have a great answer for you. But worth understanding how it's manifesting and how much it's being discussed.

The world keeps changing!

author: N
content:
I understand the perspective of (lufs don’t matter) however I want some consistency amongst my songs AND to be sufficiently loud compared to others.

I am competent of achieving very loud mixes however the introduction of artifacts bothers me. Usually I’m low passing with ISOL8 to listen for limiting/clipping clicks. These artifacts are unable to be heard unless I have a low pass filter active but I theorize that they, along with the extreme compression subconsciously degrade the listening experience by discretely assaulting your ears to the point of needing to take a break from listening. 

My music can be related sonically to clara la sans “another night” give or take more or less busy. (Keep in mind her stuff is cranked to the point of audible artifacts sitting around -7ish lufs integrated across the chorus).

I arrange the mix well and leave 1db of headroom for summing on individual instruments whilst they are loud enough for my target of -10 LUFi across the chorus, meaning my mix is actually 1db louder than -10 with space to sum on the pre master bus. Leaving headroom means I can introduce less artifacts at the cost of having to squeeze the dynamic range of individual instruments more than otherwise.

My issue is that If I want to aim for let’s say -8LUFSi across the chorus in a relatively clean way with minimal artifacts, I’m forced to squeeze the mix to -7.

I’d love to hear y’all thoughts on whether or not technically inaudible artifacts/distortion matter and whether or not it’s really worth for me to squeeze my mix 2db more in the name of competitive loudness?

Ps. Please bear with me as I am trying to figure this all out solo. Feel free to criticize my approach.

author: cian riordan
content: It's not a panacea, and it's still a long long road to be able to churn out consistently good sounding mixes. But having a reference gives you some footing to make decisions on. How much low end, how bright, how loud, vocal balances, punchiness, etc.

author: James Cronier
content: Sometimes I find if it's a faster tune, there may not be as much room for big lows as a slower one. If you're reffing against something that has more room in the time domain for a huge pushed kick drum, you may feel disapointed by yours, when it's not lacking. I find this more relevant with programmed/electronic drums and bass. I'm talking vastly different tempos not 1-5 bpm.
